paragraphs: Special | Bena Charity for Human Development for Human Development (BCFHD)
Within the project “The Integrated Livelihood Support in Famine Risk prone areas in Yemen- Dhubab District Taiz”, a specialized veterinary team today visited Dhubab District in Taiz Governorate.

The team consisted of the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO), represented by Dr. Abdul Karim Al-Bukair, and the representative of the Ministry of Agriculture, Irrigation and Fishery Walefare (MAIFW) Dr. Owsan Muhammad Saleh, in addition to Dr. Dirham Al-Qadasi, President of the Veterinary Association, and the participation of Dr. Faisal Al-Sabri, BCFHD Livelihood Projects Coordinator.

The quarantine, where the quarantined sheep were inspected was visited to inspect the quarantied female goats and ensure their safety, in addition to reviewing the results of the veterinary examination before distributing them.

It is worth mentioning that the project, as part of its package of services, includes distributing 6,000 heads of productive female goats to 1,500 families in the Dhubab District, at a rate of 4 heads per family. This aim at improving pastoral livelihoods and improving families’ food sewurity and nutrition of these targeted families.

pages.title: Integrates livelihood support for food provision and nutrition improvement for vulnerable pastoralist HHs. – BCFHD
pages.summary: Integrates livelihood support for food provision and nutrition improvement for vulnerable pastoralist HHs
pages.content: Integrates livelihood support for food provision and nutrition improvement for vulnerable pastoralist HHs. On Saturday, December 2, 2023 and within the project as part of “The Integrated Livelihood Support in Famine Risk Prone Areas in Yemen- Dhubab District Taiz” funded by United Nations Central Emergency Response Fund in cooperation with United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO), BCFHD launched the activity of distributing female goats to vulnerable pastoralist families in the Dhubab district of Taiz Governorate. It’s worth mentioning that the activity targets 1,500 families, providing them with a total of 6,000 female goats, 4 goats each HHs. This activity is part of the integrated set of livelihood support initiatives, including the distribution of animal feed and cash assistance, as well as providing awareness training for families about nutrition and modern and effective animal husbandry practices. Dr. Faisal Al-Sabri, the Livelihood Projects Coordinator at BCFHD, emphasized that the project aims to support the livelihoods of vulnerable pastoralist families with small holdings, in order to enhance their access to food and improve nutrition for approximately 10,500 individuals in the Dhubab district, which is classified as one of the most famine-prone districts. He also highlighted the implementation of various measures to ensure the safety of the goats before distribution, including a 14-day veterinary quarantine period, as well as providing veterinary care and proper nutrition. Additionally, strict protocols for transportation and secure distribution of goats are being followed under the supervision of specialized veterinarians from the Ministry of Agriculture and Irrigation. The activity implementation was attended by CCs, social leaders and representatives of local council in the district.

pages.title: “Inauguration of A Three-month Cleaning Campaign Activity”. – BCFHD
pages.summary: “Inauguration of A Three-month Cleaning Campaign Activity”
pages.content: “Inauguration of A Three-month Cleaning Campaign Activity”. In a significant step towards promoting cleanliness and public health, the “Cleanliness Campaign” activity was inaugurated this morning as part of the project ” Provision of Comprehensive Emergency and Life-saving WASH Assistance to Vulnerable IDPs and Host Communities in Salh and Al Qahirah Districts – Taiz” in Yemen. This project is funded by the Yemen Humanitarian Fund (YHF) and implemented by the Bena Charity for Human Development (BCFHD) through the Cleanliness and Improvement Fund – Taiz. The inauguration was attended by Mr. Aaref Alyousefi, Director of the Salh District, Mr. Abdelmalik Ameen, General Secretary of the Al-Qahira District, Ms. Iftihan Almashhori, Director of the Cleanliness and Improvement Fund, Mr. Ali Qaid, Executive Unit Director, Mr. Tawfiq Abdelkhabeer, Secretary-General of BCFHD, and Executive Director of BCFHD, Mr. Tareq Alhamadi, The Cleanliness Campaign aims to improve the environmental and general cleanliness in the targeted areas and raise awareness among Internally Displaced Persons (IDPs) and host communities about the importance of personal and environmental cleanliness. The campaigns will last for three months and include a variety of activities related to cleanliness, such as street and public area cleaning, and distribution of basic and consumable health and cleanliness supplies. The Cleanliness Campaigns are part of the comprehensive project to improve health and cleanliness in the targeted areas. These efforts are part of the collaborative work between the Yemen Humanitarian Fund and BCFHD to meet the needs of IDPs and vulnerable host communities. BCFHD’s Executive Director, Mr. Tareq Alhamadi, emphasized the importance of this activity, considering maintaining cleanliness and public health vital under the challenging conditions experienced by IDPs and host communities in the targeted districts. This initiative reflects the determination to improve the quality of life and provide a better health environment for everyone. Project Manager, Mr. Marwan Saeed, expressed gratitude to the Yemen Humanitarian Fund for supporting this important project. It contributes to improving our environment and public health, and he emphasized the ongoing collaboration to achieve positive results and a real impact in our daily lives. The Cleanliness Campaigns are expected to have a positive impact on public health, disease prevention, and health awareness among IDPs and host communities. The campaigns will provide guidance and training to promote good cleanliness practices and enhance prevention of prevalent diseases. This project reflects the strong partnership between the Yemen Humanitarian Fund and BCFHD in addressing emergency needs and providing necessary assistance to IDPs and vulnerable host communities. Many individuals are expected to benefit from this initiative, experiencing tangible improvements in their quality of life. This step is part of ongoing efforts to improve life in affected areas in Yemen and overcome environmental and health challenges. It underscores the commitment of BCFHD and the Yemen Humanitarian Fund to provide assistance and support to local communities in facing challenges and building a better future for everyone.

pages.title: Within support from Yemen Humanitarian Fund (YHF), BCFHD has successfully disbursed the first round of cash incentives to volunteer teachers in the Maqbanah district. – BCFHD
pages.summary: Within support from Yemen Humanitarian Fund (YHF), BCFHD has successfully disbursed the first round of cash incentives to volunteer teachers in the Maqbanah district
pages.content: Within support from Yemen Humanitarian Fund (YHF), BCFHD has successfully disbursed the first round of cash incentives to volunteer teachers in the Maqbanah district. In commemoration of International Volunteer Day, BCFHD commenced the distribution of the first round of cash incentives to both male and female volunteer teachers in the Maqbanah district. This activity is part of the larger project titled “Provision of integrated response of education and child protection services to the most vulnerable children in Maqbanah district, Taiz,” which is funded by the YHF. A total of 77 volunteer teachers will benefit from the cash incentives provided by BCFHD in this initial distribution. The distribution of cash incentives will continue for a period of 8 months, with the primary objective of boosting motivation and encouraging volunteer teachers to excel in their roles, thereby enhancing the overall quality of education in the region. This activity is an integral part of BCFHD’s comprehensive strategy to support education and improve learning opportunities for children. It encompasses various components, such as enhancing school infrastructure, providing educational materials, and offering training programs for teachers in the most affected areas. The ultimate aim is to create a safe and stimulating learning environment for the most vulnerable children in the district, empowering them and improving their educational prospects for the future. Mr. Zaid Al-Amri, the project manager, underscored that this significant step reflects BCFHD’s unwavering commitment to enhancing the capabilities and competencies of dedicated educational professionals, ensuring the delivery of high-quality education. Consequently, it contributes to raising students’ academic achievements and overall educational standards in the region. This activity is part of a targeted plan that includes various initiatives, such as providing school desks, constructing additional classrooms, distributing student kits, equipping teachers with necessary supplies, installing solar systems, and offering hygiene kits, among other endeavors. The inauguration ceremony was attended by Mr. Hamid Al-Khulaidi, the Director of the Maqbanah District, who commended BCFHD for its pivotal role in supporting education. Additionally, Mr. Mohamed Al-Kadihi, the manager of the Education Office in Maqbanah, highlighted the pressing shortage of teachers in the district’s schools and affirmed that this particular initiative addresses a significant gap in the educational needs of the directorate.

pages.title: BCFHD concludes the training program for protection teams in Maqbanah District. – BCFHD
pages.summary: BCFHD concludes the training program for protection teams in Maqbanah District
pages.content: BCFHD concludes the training program for protection teams in Maqbanah District. Continuing its efforts to provide support and care for the most vulnerable children in Yemen, BCFHD has concluded its training program for protection teams in Maqbanah District. This training program is part of the project “Integrated Response for Education and Protection Services for the Most Vulnerable Children in Maqbanah District, Taiz,” funded by the Yemen Humanitarian Fund (YHF). The training program included training for several specialized teams in child protection. The following teams participated in the training: 1. Child Protection Committees (CPCs) Training: Twenty-four trainees were trained to work in the field of child protection. 2. Project Field Team Training: Ten field team members were trained to implement the project and provide integrated services for children. 3. Friendly Spaces Team Training: Ten participants were trained in establishing and enhancing safe and child-friendly spaces. 4. Social Workers Team Training: Seven trainees, who are social workers, were trained to identify children at protection risk and make case management referrals. 5. MHPSS Team Training: Ten MHPSS facilitators were trained to provide home-based MHPSS support for children affected by conflict circumstances. The training program represents an important step in enhancing the capabilities of specialized teams to provide protection and care for vulnerable children. The project aims to have a positive impact on the lives of children and the local community in the region, as well as enhancing their opportunities for education and development. Mr. Zaid Al-Amari, the project manager, expressed his gratitude to the YHF for their continuous support. He added that the conclusion of the training program is a significant achievement and reflects BCFHD’s ongoing commitment to humanitarian work and providing support to children and needy communities in Yemen. It is expected that this program will have a positive impact on the lives of children and the community in the region, contributing to the provision of a safe and stimulating environment for their growth and development.

pages.title: Bena Charity (BCFHD) organizes a training course on “Fundamentals of drafting proposals” for 16 staff members. – BCFHD
pages.summary: Bena Charity (BCFHD) organizes a training course on “Fundamentals of drafting proposals” for 16 staff members
pages.content: Bena Charity (BCFHD) organizes a training course on “Fundamentals of drafting proposals” for 16 staff members. Bena Charity (BCFHD) held a training course on “The fundamentals of drafting proposals”, which benefited 16 humanitarian staff and staff, where the course was organized in collaboration with trainers Mr. Riyadh Salam and Mr. Riyadh AL-Shamiri. The course aims to strengthen participants’ capacities to formulate proposals and improve their skills in making effective proposals for the development of humanitarian enterprises. The course was designed in an interactive and practical manner, allowing participants to apply the concepts and tools presented in the context of their daily work. BCFHD commended the quality and effectiveness of the training course in developing participants’ abilities. Mr. Issam Abdul Ghaffar, the Director of Human Resources at BCFHD, expressed his thanks and appreciation to the trainers who provided knowledge and expertise. He added: “This training course has been a valuable opportunity for our staff to improve their skills in drafting proposals and enhance their capacity to make successful proposals for human development. We are grateful to the trainers for their efforts to guide participants and provide knowledge in a distinct and inspiring manner. ” Ongoing trainings and workshops are an essential part of BCFHD’s strategies in developing its team capabilities and achieving its humanitarian goals. This valuable training is expected to reflect on the quality of projects and initiatives offered by BCFHD for the benefit of the target communities.

pages.title: Funded by Pure Hands.. Launch of the Agricultural Village Development Programme (distillation irrigation system distribution phase and manual tillage in Al-Mawaset Directorate ) – BCFHD
pages.summary: Funded by Pure Hands
pages.content: Funded by Pure Hands.. Launch of the Agricultural Village Development Programme (distillation irrigation system distribution phase and manual tillage in Al-Mawaset Directorate ) Pure Hands organization has provided subvention for the Rural Agricultural Development Program, specifically the phase involving the distribution of water distributing systems and manual plows in the Al-Mawasat Directorate.Bena Charity for Human Development (BCFHD) has launched this initiative with the aim of supporting the agricultural sector and improving water efficiency in the region. The program targets 80 farms in 10 agricultural villages across the Al-Mawasat and Al-Shamaytin directorates. Today, distribution took place for 40 farms in five agricultural villages associated with the Al-Akhmor Isolation in Al-Mawasat, while distribution for the remaining farmers in the Duba Al-Kharej Isolation in the Al-Shamaytin Directorate will be completed at a later time. The inauguration event was attended by several notable individuals, including the Deputy Governor for Quarries Affairs, Mr. Mohammed Abdulaziz Al-Sanawi, the Director of Al-Mawasat Directorate, Mr. Ameen Sharaf Thabit, the Director of the Agriculture Office in Al-Mawasat, Mr. Ali Al-Soufi. Additionally, representatives from Pure Hands organization, Engineer Ibrahim Saleh, and the Executive Director of Bena Charity for Human Development, Mr. Tariq Al-Hammadi, along with Engineer Suleiman Al-Samadi, the Project Manager, were present. Mr. Mohammed Al-Sanawi, the Deputy Governor, expressed his appreciation for the activity, highlighting its role in continuously improving and developing the agricultural sector. He emphasized that this initiative will contribute to enhancing agricultural sustainability and achieving food security in the region. Engineer Ibrahim Saleh, representing Pure Hands organization, expressed pride in funding this crucial project, which aims to promote sustainable agriculture and improve the living conditions of farmers. The organization is committed to supporting rural communities and providing the necessary tools to enhance agricultural productivity and sustainability. Mr. Tariq Al-Hammadi, the Executive Director of BCFHD, emphasized the Association’s pride in participating in this activity, as they firmly believe in the importance of supporting and enhancing the agricultural sector. This initiative is a significant step in that direction, underscoring the Association’s commitment to providing farmers with the necessary support and resources to improve productivity and enhance agricultural sustainability in the region. It is important to note that this activity is a significant milestone in the agricultural sector’s development within the directorate. The modern water distributing system will improve efficiency and water usage, ultimately leading to increased farm productivity and improved living conditions for farmers.

The inauguration event was attended by several notable individuals, including the Deputy Governor for Quarries Affairs, Mr. Mohammed Abdulaziz Al-Sanawi, the Director of Al-Mawasat Directorate, Mr. Ameen Sharaf Thabit, the Director of the Agriculture Office in Al-Mawasat, Mr. Ali Al-Soufi. Additionally, representatives from Pure Hands organization, Engineer Ibrahim Saleh, and the Executive Director of Bena Charity for Human Development, Mr. Tariq Al-Hammadi, along with Engineer Suleiman Al-Samadi, the Project Manager, were present. Mr. Mohammed Al-Sanawi, the Deputy Governor, expressed his appreciation for the activity, highlighting its role in continuously improving and developing the agricultural sector. He emphasized that this initiative will contribute to enhancing agricultural sustainability and achieving food security in the region. Engineer Ibrahim Saleh, representing Pure Hands organization, expressed pride in funding this crucial project, which aims to promote sustainable agriculture and improve the living conditions of farmers. The organization is committed to supporting rural communities and providing the necessary tools to enhance agricultural productivity and sustainability. Mr. Tariq Al-Hammadi, the Executive Director of BCFHD, emphasized the Association’s pride in participating in this activity, as they firmly believe in the importance of supporting and enhancing the agricultural sector. This initiative is a significant step in that direction, underscoring the Association’s commitment to providing farmers with the necessary support and resources to improve productivity and enhance agricultural sustainability in the region. It is important to note that this activity is a significant milestone in the agricultural sector’s development within the directorate. The modern water distributing system will improve efficiency and water usage, ultimately leading to increased farm productivity and improved living conditions for farmers.

pages.title: Continuation of Building 10 Rainwater Harvesting Tanks in 10 Agricultural Villages in the Al-Mawasit and Al-Shamaytin Directorates, as part of the Rural Development and Revitalization Project. – BCFHD
pages.summary: Continuation of Building 10 Rainwater Harvesting Tanks in 10 Agricultural Villages in the Al-Mawasit and Al-Shamaytin Directorates, as part of the Rural Development and Revitalization Project
pages.content: Continuation of Building 10 Rainwater Harvesting Tanks in 10 Agricultural Villages in the Al-Mawasit and Al-Shamaytin Directorates, as part of the Rural Development and Revitalization Project. We live in an era where the world is striving for resource sustainability and environmental preservation. In this context, Pure Hands Organization and Bena Charity for Human Development (BCFHD) are implementing the Rural Development and Revitalization Project in the Al-Mawasit and Al-Shamaytin Directorates. This project aims to support farmers and alleviate their hardships by constructing rainwater harvesting tanks in 10 different agricultural villages. Rainwater is a valuable natural resource for farmers as it provides a sustainable source for agricultural irrigation. Through the construction of tanks, rainwater is collected and stored for use during dry periods, ensuring year-round agriculture. This approach is crucial in improving crop productivity and enhancing the sustainability of agricultural villages. Alongside the tank construction, modern irrigation networks and accessories are provided to the targeted farmers. These networks enhance water usage efficiency and provide a unified system for distributing water to crops in an effective and sustainable manner. Training and awareness programs are provided to farmers to ensure maximum benefit from these modern techniques and to achieve success in their agricultural endeavors.

pages.title: BCFHD distributes second instalment of cash incentives to volunteer teachers in Maqbanah district, Yemen – BCFHD
pages.summary: BCFHD distributes second instalment of cash incentives to volunteer teachers in Maqbanah district, Yemen BCFHD distributed the second instalment of cash incentives to volunteer teachers in...
pages.content: BCFHD distributes second instalment of cash incentives to volunteer teachers in Maqbanah district, Yemen BCFHD distributed the second instalment of cash incentives to volunteer teachers in Maqbanah district, Tai’zz governorate, on December 28, 2023. The incentives are part of the “Provision of integrated response of education and child protection services to the most vulnerable children in Maqbanah district, Taiz,” project, funded by the Humanitarian Fund for Yemen (YHF). The second instalment benefited 77 teachers, 45 of whom are female and 32 are male. It is the second of eight monthly installments for volunteers. The aim of providing cash incentives to volunteer teachers is to boost their motivation and encourage them to perform their duties and improve the quality of education in the region. “This step reflects our commitment to supporting volunteer teachers in fulfilling their noble mission and improving the quality of education in the region,” said Eng. Zaid Al-Amri, project manager. He added that BCFHD aims to distribute cash incentives to more than 600 volunteer teachers in Maqbanah district during the project.

pages.title: Bena Charity Distributes Second Batch of Irrigation and Hand Plows to Farmers Funded by Pure Hands Organization. – BCFHD
pages.summary: Bena Charity Distributes Second Batch of Irrigation and Hand Plows to Farmers Funded by Pure Hands Organization
pages.content: Bena Charity Distributes Second Batch of Irrigation and Hand Plows to Farmers Funded by Pure Hands Organization. Bena Charity, funded by Pure Hands organization, launched the second batch of irrigation networks and hand plows distribution activity to farmers as part of the Agricultural Villages Development Project in Al-Shamayteen and Al-Mawasit districts of Ta’izz governorate. The distribution included 40 farmers in five agricultural villages, four of which are in Al-Shamayteen district, Deb Al-Kharej district, and one in Al-Mawasit district, Al-Akhmor district. The launching was attended by Mr. Muhammad Mahmoud, head of the Services Committee in the local council of Al-Shamayteen district, Mr. Sultan Al-Asbahi, director of the Agriculture Office in Al-Shamayteen district, Mr. Muhammad Al-Maqtari, representative of Pure Hands organization, Mr. Tawfiq Abdul-Khabir, secretary-general of BCFHD, and Mr. Suleiman Al-Samadi, project manager. Mr. Muhammad Al-Maqtari, representative of Pure Hands organization, stressed that the project aims to promote agricultural sustainability and achieve food security in Ta’izz governorate. For his part, Mr. Tawfiq Abdul-Khabir, secretary-general of BCFHD, thanked Pure Hands organization for supporting this project, and expressed his hope that the project would contribute to improving the living standards of farmers and increasing their agricultural production. The beneficiaries of the project praised the efforts of the association and the supporting organization, confirming that the project will contribute to increasing their agricultural production and improving their income.

pages.title: Bena Charity Lays Foundation for 12 Classrooms Construction Project in Maqbanah. – BCFHD
pages.summary: Bena Charity Lays Foundation for 12 Classrooms Construction Project in Maqbanah
pages.content: Bena Charity Lays Foundation for 12 Classrooms Construction Project in Maqbanah. Ta’izz – January 4, 2024 BCFHD, funded by the Humanitarian Fund, and under the patronage of the local authorities in Maqbanah district and the Ministry of Education, laid the foundation stone for a project to build 12 classrooms in three schools in Maqbanah district in Ta’izz governorate. The groundbreaking ceremony was attended by the director of the provincial education office, Abdulwasee’ Shaddad, the director general of Maqbanah district, Hamid Ghalib Al-Khulidi, the deputy director of the Social Affairs Office, Dr. Mahmoud Al-Bakkari, and the director of BCFHD, Tariq Al-Hammadi. Abdulwasee’ Shaddad, the director of the education office, said that the project aims to provide a suitable educational environment for students and teachers in Maqbanah district, which is suffering from a tragic situation in various fields and sectors. Shaddad praised the efforts of BCFHD in implementing educational projects in a number of governorate’s districts, describing it as one of the leading organizations in providing educational and pedagogical interventions. For his part, Hamid Ghalib Al-Khulidi, the director general of Maqbanah district, explained that the project contributes to enhancing the level of participation and interaction in the educational process, and carries a strong message to students and teachers that education is important and that achieving educational success is a top priority. Tariq Al-Hammadi, the director of BCFHD, mentioned that the project also includes the distribution of 2,956 school bags to students and teachers in 10 schools in the district, the distribution of 100 teacher bags in 15 schools, the distribution of 60 white boards in 13 schools, in addition to providing 7 solar systems, 7 cleaning bags, 370 double-seats, and supporting 77 teachers with financial incentives for 8 months. Al-Hammadi added that the project aims to provide a comprehensive response to education and protection services for the most affected children in Maqbanah district. The ceremony was also attended by the director of the Maqbanah district education administration, Muhammad Al-Kidahi, the director of the association’s education project, Zaid Al-Amiri, the director of public relations of the provincial education office, Mahmoud Al-Tayar, the education project staff of the association, and a number of local dignitaries and school principals.

pages.title: BCFHD Launches Cash for Work Program in AL-Maafer and Maqbanah Districts. – BCFHD
pages.summary: BCFHD Launches Cash for Work Program in AL-Maafer and Maqbanah Districts
pages.content: BCFHD Launches Cash for Work Program in AL-Maafer and Maqbanah Districts. Ta’izz, Yemen – January 4, 2024 (BCFHD) in partnership with Oxfam launched a cash for work program in AL-Maafer and Maqbanah districts of Ta’izz governorate, funded by the UK Foreign, Commonwealth and Development Office. The program is part of the “Building Resilience Through Integrated Community-Based and Humanitarian Systems Transformation and Leadership in Yemen” project. The program aims to support the poorest families in the two districts by providing them with temporary employment opportunities that enable them to meet their basic needs. This will be done through their participation in the rehabilitation and paving of rough roads, which are the main and only artery for the movement of citizens between different villages and markets in the targeted areas. During the launch, Mr. Sami Al-Duba’i, the project manager, said: “We are pleased to launch this important project, given the positive impact it will have on improving the difficult living conditions of the targeted communities that lack the most basic necessities of life in light of the ongoing war and recurring natural disasters. This project reflects our commitment to supporting local communities affected by the war in Yemen.”

pages.title: Monthly meeting of child protection committees in Maqbanah district. – BCFHD
pages.summary: Monthly meeting of child protection committees in Maqbanah district
pages.content: Monthly meeting of child protection committees in Maqbanah district. On Sunday, January 7, 2024, the second monthly meeting of child protection committees was held in Maqbanah district, Taiz governorate, as part of the project to Provision of integrated response of education and child protection services to the most vulnerable children in Maqbanah district, Taiz, funded by YHF. The meeting included a case management officer, case management supervisors, social workers, and child protection committees. During the meeting, the activities that took place during the past month were discussed, which included awareness-raising about child rights, studying the cases of vulnerable children under case management, and developing an implementation mechanism. The challenges and obstacles facing the work were also discussed to ensure its progress in a coordinated manner towards achieving the project’s goals. The participants in the meeting stressed the importance of coordination between the various stakeholders in child protection to provide the necessary care for the most vulnerable children in the district. The meeting comes within the framework of the efforts being made by the stakeholders in child protection in Yemen to ensure the rights of children and provide them with care.

pages.title: Bena Charity (BCFHD) Opens Agricultural Village Project in Taiz, Funded by Pure Hands. – BCFHD
pages.summary: Bena Charity (BCFHD) Opens Agricultural Village Project in Taiz, Funded by Pure Hands Bena Charity (BCFHD) opened on Thursday its Agricultural Village Project in Taiz governorate, funded by Pure Hands
pages.content: Bena Charity (BCFHD) Opens Agricultural Village Project in Taiz, Funded by Pure Hands. Bena Charity (BCFHD) opened on Thursday its Agricultural Village Project in Taiz governorate, funded by Pure Hands. The project aims to support farmers in Taiz governorate and alleviate their suffering by building 10 rainwater harvesting tanks in 10 agricultural villages. The villages benefiting from the project include 6 villages in Mawasit district, AL-Akhmor district, and 4 villages in AL-Shmaaiten district in Dhaba’ Al-Kharej district. Each tank benefits 8 farmers in each village, for a total of 80 farmers benefiting from the tanks. The opening ceremony was attended by Najeeb Ghazi, director of Pure Hands office in Sana’a, Mersal Al-Sahbany, program manager at the organization, Amin Sharaf Thabet, director of Ma’wasit district, Ali Abdulrahman Al-Sofyani, director of agriculture office in Ma’wasit district, Riyadh Salaam, program manager at BCFHD, and Suleiman Al-Samadi, project manager. Najeeb Ghazi stressed that the agricultural village project comes within the framework of Pure Hands’ efforts to enhance food security and improve the livelihoods of farmers in Yemen. Riyadh Salaam, for his part, explained that the project aims to collect and store rainwater to provide a sustainable source of agricultural irrigation, which will contribute to improving crop yields and enhancing the sustainability of agricultural villages. The beneficiaries of the project expressed their happiness with the implementation of this project, which will contribute to improving their lives and increasing their income. This initiative comes within the framework of BCFHD’s efforts to promote sustainable development in Yemen.

Riyadh Salaam, for his part, explained that the project aims to collect and store rainwater to provide a sustainable source of agricultural irrigation, which will contribute to improving crop yields and enhancing the sustainability of agricultural villages. The beneficiaries of the project expressed their happiness with the implementation of this project, which will contribute to improving their lives and increasing their income. This initiative comes within the framework of BCFHD’s efforts to promote sustainable development in Yemen.

headings.text: Bena Charity (BCFHD) Opens Agricultural Village Project in Taiz, Funded by Pure Hands.

paragraphs: Bena Charity (BCFHD) opened on Thursday its Agricultural Village Project in Taiz governorate, funded by Pure Hands.
The project aims to support farmers in Taiz governorate and alleviate their suffering by building 10 rainwater harvesting tanks in 10 agricultural villages.
The villages benefiting from the project include 6 villages in Mawasit district, AL-Akhmor district, and 4 villages in AL-Shmaaiten district in Dhaba’ Al-Kharej district.
Each tank benefits 8 farmers in each village, for a total of 80 farmers benefiting from the tanks.

The opening ceremony was attended by Najeeb Ghazi, director of Pure Hands office in Sana’a, Mersal Al-Sahbany, program manager at the organization, Amin Sharaf Thabet, director of Ma’wasit district, Ali Abdulrahman Al-Sofyani, director of agriculture office in Ma’wasit district, Riyadh Salaam, program manager at BCFHD, and Suleiman Al-Samadi, project manager.

pages.title: BCFHD Holds Training Course on Institutional Leadership Methodology and Depth of Change. – BCFHD
pages.summary: BCFHD Holds Training Course on Institutional Leadership Methodology and Depth of Change
pages.content: BCFHD Holds Training Course on Institutional Leadership Methodology and Depth of Change. BCFHD held a training course on “Institutional Leadership Methodology and Depth of Change,” which benefited 37 trainees from various humanitarian organizations in Taiz. The course was presented by trainer Najib Ghazi, who discussed the concept of institutional leadership, its characteristics, and its types. He also discussed the role of leadership in bringing about change in organizations. The course focused on a number of important topics, including: * The concept of institutional leadership and its importance * The characteristics of institutional leadership * The types of institutional leadership * The role of leadership in bringing about deep change * Institutional leadership skills At the end of the course, the participants thanked BCFHD for organizing this valuable course and emphasized the importance of the role of institutional leadership in bringing about positive change in organizations. The course is part of the efforts of BCFHD to support humanitarian workers and provide them with the skills and knowledge they need to perform their duties to the fullest.

pages.title: Mr. Riyad Ahmed receives his Ph.D. in translation with excellence. – BCFHD
pages.summary: Mr Riyad Ahmed receives his Ph D in translation with excellence
pages.content: Mr. Riyad Ahmed receives his Ph.D. in translation with excellence. Bena Charity for Human Development (BCFHD) is pleased to extend its warmest congratulations and heartfelt wishes to our dear colleague Mr. Riyad Ahmed Abdulmughni Abdulghani, the Monitoring and Evaluation Officer, on the occasion of earning his Ph.D. in Translation with distinction. We, at BCFHD, take great pride in your accomplishments and appreciate your dedication and efforts in serving the community and promoting human development. Your active presence as a member of our team means a lot to us, and we look forward to a bright future with your valuable contributions and excellent leadership. Once again, we congratulate you on achieving your Ph.D. in Translation, and we wish you every success in your future professional and academic journey. Warm regards, Management and Staff of BCFHD

pages.title: Bena Charity disburses the third installment of financial incentives to volunteer teachers in Maqbanah district on the occasion of World Education Day. – BCFHD
pages.summary: Bena Charity disburses the third installment of financial incentives to volunteer teachers in Maqbanah district on the occasion of World Education Day
pages.content: Bena Charity disburses the third installment of financial incentives to volunteer teachers in Maqbanah district on the occasion of World Education Day. In conjunction with the celebration of World Education Day, Bena Charity for Humanitarian Development (BCFHD) disbursed the third installment of financial incentives to volunteer teachers in Maqbanah district, Taiz governorate, on Wednesday, January 24, 2024. This is part of the activities of the “Provision of integrated response of education and child protection services to the most vulnerable children in Maqbanah district, Taiz,”, funded by Yemen Humanitarian Fund (YHF). The number of beneficiaries from the third installment was 77 teachers, including 45 female teachers and 32 male teachers. This third installment is part of eight monthly installments, aimed at motivating and encouraging volunteer teachers to perform their work and improve the quality of education in the region. Project Manager Engineer Zaid Al-Amiri, on this occasion, stated that this step reflects the BCFHD’s commitment to supporting volunteer teachers in fulfilling their noble mission and improving the quality of education in the region. He added that the BCFHD seeks through this project to provide a safe and stimulating environment for the most affected children in the district, in order to enhance their educational opportunities and future. Al-Amiri said: “The occasion of World Education Day provides an appropriate opportunity to highlight the importance of education and its role in building a better future for future generations. We at BCFHD believe that education is a fundamental right for all children, and therefore, through this project, we seek to provide educational opportunities for everyone, including children living in conflict and disaster areas.” Al-Amiri added: “We thank Yemen Humanitarian Fund (YHF) for its support of this project, which contributes to enhancing our efforts to improve the quality of education in Maqbanah district.”

pages.title: BCFHD inaugurates an activity to Provide Chlorine to 23 Wells in Salah and Al-Qahirah Districts. – BCFHD
pages.summary: BCFHD inaugurates an activity to Provide Chlorine to 23 Wells in Salah and Al-Qahirah Districts
pages.content: BCFHD inaugurates an activity to Provide Chlorine to 23 Wells in Salah and Al-Qahirah Districts. On Wednesday morning, BCFHD inaugurated the activity “Providing chlorine for chlorination of 23 wells that feed water networks in Salh and Al-Qahirah districts for 5 months, and maintenance of 15 chlorine injectors” within the project “Provision of Comprehensive Emergency and Life-saving WASH Assistance to Vulnerable IDPs and Host Communities in Salh and Al Qahirah Districts” funded by the Yemen Humanitarian Fund (YHF). The inauguration was attended by representatives of the local authority in the two districts, representatives of the Water Corporation and BCFHD.

pages.title: Bena Charity inaugurates Hygiene Kit Distribution Activity in Salh and Al Qahirah Districts. – BCFHD
pages.summary: Bena Charity inaugurates Hygiene Kit Distribution Activity in Salh and Al Qahirah Districts
pages.content: Bena Charity inaugurates Hygiene Kit Distribution Activity in Salh and Al Qahirah Districts. BCFHD inaugrated the distribution of hygiene kits (basic and consumable) in Salh and Al Qahirah districts of Taiz governorate that will last for 3 months, as part of the project “Provision of Comprehensive Emergency and Life-saving WASH Assistance to Vulnerable IDPs and Host Communities in Salh and Al Qahirah Districts – Taiz.”. The project is funded by the Yemen Humanitarian Fund and aims to provide essential personal hygiene supplies to IDPs and host communities in the two districts, targeting 3000 BNFs, including PWDs, People with Chronic Diseases, and Marginalized groups, which will contribute to improving personal hygiene practices and preventing the spread of diseases.

pages.title: BCFHD obtains membership in the strategic advisory group for the water and sanitation (WASH)sector in Yemen. – BCFHD
pages.summary: BCFHD obtains membership in the strategic advisory group for the water and sanitation (WASH)sector in Yemen
pages.content: BCFHD obtains membership in the strategic advisory group for the water and sanitation (WASH)sector in Yemen. Bena Charity for Human Development (BCFHD) has obtained membership in the Strategic Advisory Group (SAG) for the Water and Sanitation Sector (WASH) in Yemen, for a period of two years. The tasks of the strategic advisory group include: Strategic Planning: Develop strategic plans to improve water, sanitation and hygiene services in Yemen. Coordination: Ensure coordination between different actors in the WASH sector. Verification of action plans: Review of action plans submitted by organizations working in the sector. Advocacy and Awareness: Spreading awareness about the importance of WASH services. Integration between different teams: Ensuring integration of efforts between the various teams working in the sector. Performance Monitoring: Monitoring the performance of organizations operating in the sector. Ensuring adherence to standards: Ensure all organizations adhere to international standards for WASH services. Capacity strengthening: Supporting and enhancing the capabilities of organizations working in the sector. Accountability of stakeholders: Ensure accountability of all stakeholders in the sector. Publishing the results: publishing the results of the work periodically. The strategic advisory group consists of: International non-governmental organizations: 3 (2 new elected, 1 from the previous cycle): elected for a period of two years. National non-governmental organizations: 3 (2 new elected, 1 from the previous cycle): elected for a period of two years. Members of the Ministry of Water and Environment: 2 automatic members of SAG. Hygiene, water and environmental sanitation coordination team number 3 (coordinator, co-ordinator and IMO). UN agencies active in emergency situations: 2 (IOM/UNICEF). With a total of 13 members. BCFHD membership in the WASH Sector Strategic Advisory Group confirms its leadership role in providing water, sanitation and hygiene services in Yemen. Through this membership, BCFHD seeks to contribute effectively to improving WASH services throughout Yemen.

pages.title: Bena Charity Distributes 370 New School Desks in Maqbanah District. – BCFHD
pages.summary: Bena Charity Distributes 370 New School Desks in Maqbanah District (BCFHD) inaugurated the distribution of 370 new school desks at Al-Zubairi School in Maqbanah District
pages.content: Bena Charity Distributes 370 New School Desks in Maqbanah District. (BCFHD) inaugurated the distribution of 370 new school desks at Al-Zubairi School in Maqbanah District. This comes within the framework of the Integrated Response Project for Education and Protection Services for the Most Affected Children in Maqbanah District, implemented by the society with funding from Yemen Humanitarian Fund (YHF). The project also includes distributing bags for students and teachers, distributing whiteboards, disbursing cash incentives for volunteer teachers, building 12 temporary classrooms, installing solar energy systems, and distributing hygiene kits. Mr. Hamid Al-Khulidi, Director General of the Directorate, expressed his thanks for the society’s efforts in various sectors in Maqbanah District, and stressed the importance of the educational services provided by the society to improve the educational level of students. Mr. Tawfiq Abdulkhaleq, Secretary-General of BCFHD, thanked the YHF for its support for the many integrated services provided to the education sector.

pages.title: BCFHD Celebrates International Women’s Day. – BCFHD
pages.summary: BCFHD Celebrates International Women’s Day This morning, the Women and Children’s Sector of BCFHD organized a remarkable event to mark International Women’s Day
pages.content: BCFHD Celebrates International Women’s Day. This morning, the Women and Children’s Sector of BCFHD organized a remarkable event to mark International Women’s Day. The event aimed to highlight women’s achievements and their central role in society under the theme “Women are the foundation of society”. The event saw a wide participation of women from different age groups, who expressed their delight in being part of this important event, emphasizing the importance of honoring women and recognizing their role in building the community. For her part, Ms. Fayda Sharaf emphasized the importance of this event in raising awareness about women’s issues and called for more efforts to appreciate the vital role that women play in society.

pages.title: General Assembly of Bena Charity Holds its Eighth Session. – BCFHD
pages.summary: General Assembly of Bena Charity Holds its Eighth Session
pages.content: General Assembly of Bena Charity Holds its Eighth Session. The General Assembly of Bena Charity for Human Development (BCFHD) concluded its “annual regular” meeting this morning in the hall of AL-Rawad University. The meeting was attended by the legal quorum of the General Assembly members and Mr. Abdo Ali, Director of the Social Affairs and Labor Office in Taiz Governorate. The session began with verses from the Holy Quran, followed by a minute of silence and the recitation of AL-Fatiha in memory of the late teacher and educator, Mr. Mohammed Ali Ismail. Dr. Abdulkarim Shamsan, Head of BCFHD, then delivered a speech in which he welcomed the attendees and praised the role of the General Assembly, the Board of Directors, and the Supervisory Committee in serving the Society’s objectives and achieving its strategy of building the present and shaping the future. Dr. Shamsan presented his annual report, highlighting the Society’s most important achievements during the past period. He also addressed the most important projects and the expansion of their implementation in a number of Yemeni governorates, explaining the partnerships with many international donor and humanitarian organizations. The financial report was also presented by the legal accountant, in addition to the report of the Supervisory Committee. This was followed by an extensive discussion and inquiries from the members on the reports, which were answered. The 2024 plan and budget were also reviewed and discussed, and both were approved.

The financial report was also presented by the legal accountant, in addition to the report of the Supervisory Committee. This was followed by an extensive discussion and inquiries from the members on the reports, which were answered. The 2024 plan and budget were also reviewed and discussed, and both were approved.

headings.text: General Assembly of Bena Charity Holds its Eighth Session.

paragraphs: The General Assembly of Bena Charity for Human Development (BCFHD) concluded its “annual regular” meeting this morning in the hall of AL-Rawad University. The meeting was attended by the legal quorum of the General Assembly members and Mr. Abdo Ali, Director of the Social Affairs and Labor Office in Taiz Governorate.

The session began with verses from the Holy Quran, followed by a minute of silence and the recitation of AL-Fatiha in memory of the late teacher and educator, Mr. Mohammed Ali Ismail. Dr. Abdulkarim Shamsan, Head of BCFHD, then delivered a speech in which he welcomed the attendees and praised the role of the General Assembly, the Board of Directors, and the Supervisory Committee in serving the Society’s objectives and achieving its strategy of building the present and shaping the future.

Dr. Shamsan presented his annual report, highlighting the Society’s most important achievements during the past period. He also addressed the most important projects and the expansion of their implementation in a number of Yemeni governorates, explaining the partnerships with many international donor and humanitarian organizations.
The financial report was also presented by the legal accountant, in addition to the report of the Supervisory Committee.
This was followed by an extensive discussion and inquiries from the members on the reports, which were answered. The 2024 plan and budget were also reviewed and discussed, and both were approved.

pages.title: Bena Charity Holds Training Course for its Employees on Humanitarian Work Standards. – BCFHD
pages.summary: Bena Charity Holds Training Course for its Employees on Humanitarian Work Standards
pages.content: Bena Charity Holds Training Course for its Employees on Humanitarian Work Standards. On the morning of March 10, 2024, Bena Charity organized a training course for its employees entitled “Humanitarian Work Standards.” The course targeted 22 employees from different departments of BCFHD. The course aimed to familiarize employees with international humanitarian work standards and enhance their capacity to apply these standards in various stages of humanitarian work, starting from assessment and needs, through planning and implementation, to follow-up and evaluation. During the course, trainer Majdi Al-Qubati covered many important topics, including: Humanitarian work principles Accountability and transparency standards Community participation Emergency response Assessment and monitoring The management of Benaa Charity Association expressed its thanks and appreciation to the trainer Majdi Al-Qabati for his efforts in making the course a success. It also expressed its happiness with the active participation of the employees and the information they acquired during the course.

pages.title: Bena Charity Concludes “Cash for Work” Distributions in Al-Ma’afir and Maqbanah. – BCFHD
pages.summary: Bena Charity Concludes “Cash for Work” Distributions in Al-Ma’afir and Maqbanah
pages.content: Bena Charity Concludes “Cash for Work” Distributions in Al-Ma’afir and Maqbanah. BCFHD, in partnership with Oxfam, concluded the fourth and final round of “Cash for Work” distributions to 199 households in Al-Ma’afir and Maqbanah districts of Taiz governorate. The project was funded by the UK Foreign, Commonwealth and Development Office. This activity is part of the project “Building Resilience Through Integrated Community-Based and Humanitarian Systems Transformation and Leadership in Yemen”.

pages.title: Bena Charity Distributes Fifth Round of Cash Incentives to Volunteer Teachers in Maqbanah. – BCFHD
pages.summary: Bena Charity Distributes Fifth Round of Cash Incentives to Volunteer Teachers in Maqbanah
pages.content: Bena Charity Distributes Fifth Round of Cash Incentives to Volunteer Teachers in Maqbanah. Bena Charity (BCFHD) continues to distribute incentives to volunteer teachers in Maqbanah District, Taiz Governorate. Today, the fifth round of cash incentives was distributed as part of the “Integrated Response Project for Education and Protection Services for the Most Affected Children in Maqbanah District” funded by the Yemen Humanitarian Fund (YHF). This payment is part of 8 monthly payments that aim to boost the motivation and incentive of volunteer teachers to perform their work and improve the quality of education in the area.

pages.title: Distribution of Health Kits Vouchers to 3000 Beneficiaries in Taiz. – BCFHD
pages.summary: Distribution of Health Kits Vouchers to 3000 Beneficiaries in Taiz
pages.content: Distribution of Health Kits Vouchers to 3000 Beneficiaries in Taiz. Bena Charity (BCFHD) has distributed the second round of health kits vouchers to 3000 beneficiaries from the categories of people with disabilities, kidney failure patients, and marginalized people in the Salh and Al Qahirah districts of Taiz governorate. This activity comes within the framework of the project “Provision of Comprehensive Emergency and Life-saving WASH Assistance to Vulnerable IDPs and Host Communities in Salh and Al Qahirah Districts – Taiz”, funded by the Yemen Humanitarian Fund. Through this project, BCFHD seeks to improve the livelihoods and public health of the targeted communities by providing basic services in the field of water, sanitation and hygiene.

pages.title: Cholera: Clean water is your strongest weapon! – BCFHD
pages.summary: Cholera: Clean water is your strongest weapon
pages.content: Cholera: Clean water is your strongest weapon! Cholera is a serious disease that can cause dehydration and death if not treated promptly, but it can be easily prevented by using and drinking only clean and safe water. Why is clean water important? Cholera is spread through water contaminated with the feces of an infected person. Cholera bacteria in contaminated water can cause symptoms like diarrhea and vomiting, which can lead to dehydration and death. Ensuring that you only drink clean and safe water can prevent cholera bacteria from entering your body and keep you healthy. How to get clean water: Boil water for at least one minute before drinking it. Use a filter designed to remove bacteria from water. Drink bottled water from trusted sources. Avoid drinking water from unknown sources such as rivers, lakes, and untreated wells. Don’t wait until you get cholera, protect yourself and your family by using and drinking only clean and safe water! Share this post with your friends and family to spread awareness about the importance of clean water in preventing cholera.

pages.title: Cholera: Diarrhea is a danger sign! – BCFHD
pages.summary: Cholera: Diarrhea is a danger sign If you are experiencing diarrhea, especially if it is accompanied by other symptoms such as vomiting and fever, you may have cholera
pages.content: Cholera: Diarrhea is a danger sign! If you are experiencing diarrhea, especially if it is accompanied by other symptoms such as vomiting and fever, you may have cholera. Cholera is a serious disease that can cause dehydration and death if not treated promptly. What to do if you have diarrhea?: Drink an oral rehydration solution (ORS) immediately. You can prepare it at home by mixing clean water with salt and sugar. Go to the nearest health center immediately to receive appropriate treatment. Do not take any medication without consulting a doctor. Oral rehydration solution (ORS): ORS helps to replace fluids and salts lost by the body due to diarrhea. ORS must be prepared correctly to be effective. You can get ORS from pharmacies or health care centers. Don’t hesitate to seek help! If you have diarrhea, especially if it is accompanied by other symptoms such as vomiting and fever, seek help from the nearest health center or doctor. Delaying treatment can put your life at risk. Share this post with your friends and family to spread awareness about the dangers of cholera and the importance of seeking medical attention promptly.

pages.title: Bena Charity Illuminates 7 Schools in Maqbana with Solar Energy. – BCFHD
pages.summary: Bena Charity Illuminates 7 Schools in Maqbana with Solar Energy BCFHD today inaugurated the distribution and installation of solar energy systems in 7 schools in Maqbana District
pages.content: Bena Charity Illuminates 7 Schools in Maqbana with Solar Energy. BCFHD today inaugurated the distribution and installation of solar energy systems in 7 schools in Maqbana District. Funded by Yemen Humanitarian Fund, the project aims to improve the educational environment and provide a suitable learning environment for students. The project also includes the distribution of school bags for teachers and students, the provision of school supplies such as blackboards and desks, and the payment of incentives for volunteer teachers. The project also includes the construction of 12 temporary classrooms and the distribution of hygiene kits.

pages.title: BCFHD Hands Over Construction Sites for 12 Classrooms in Maqbana District. – BCFHD
pages.summary: BCFHD Hands Over Construction Sites for 12 Classrooms in Maqbana District BCFHD has handed over the construction sites for 12 classrooms with their health facilities in 3 schools in Maqbana District
pages.content: BCFHD Hands Over Construction Sites for 12 Classrooms in Maqbana District. BCFHD has handed over the construction sites for 12 classrooms with their health facilities in 3 schools in Maqbana District. The project is funded by Yemen Humanitarian Fund. The sites were handed over in three schools: Al-Azhar School in Uzaybah Al-Qihefah, Al-Anwar School in Uzaybah Al-Yaman, and Bilal Bin Rabah School in Uzaybah Al-Qihefah. This is part of “Integrated Response Project for Education and Protection Services for the Most Affected Children in Maqbanah District” project. The handover was attended by a number of local figures, council members, school administration, teachers, and citizens.

pages.summary: Cholera: Handwashing is essential at these times
pages.content: Cholera: Handwashing is essential at these times! To prevent the spread of cholera, make sure to wash your hands with soap and water at these times: After using the toilet Before preparing food Before eating After cleaning children Before feeding children Handwashing with soap is one of the most important ways to prevent the spread of cholera and other diseases. Make sure to wash your hands frequently to stay healthy and protect those around you.

pages.title: Delivery of new housing unit contracts to 20 displaced families in the district of Mafar Ta’izz. – BCFHD
pages.summary: Delivery of new housing unit contracts to 20 displaced families in the district of Mafar Ta’izz
pages.content: Delivery of new housing unit contracts to 20 displaced families in the district of Mafar Ta’izz. In a heartwarming ceremony, 20 displaced families in Ma’afir district, Taizz Governorate, today received contracts for new housing units, thanks to joint efforts between Bena Charity and Pure Hands Organization, in coordination with the Executive Unit for Displaced Persons. During the handover ceremony, First Deputy Governor of Taizz Dr. Abdulqawi Al-Mikhlafi expressed his gratitude and appreciation to international and local organizations, especially Pure Hands Organization, for their continuous support for the displaced in the governorate, praising the efforts of Bena Charity in implementing the project on the ground. Dr. Al-Mikhlafi affirmed the local authority’s commitment, led by Governor Nabil Shamsan, to provide all necessary facilities to organizations working in the humanitarian field, in the belief of the importance of their role in alleviating the suffering of the displaced and those affected by the war. For his part, Chairman of BCFHD Dr. Abdulkarim Shamsan explained that the project includes the construction of 20 housing units, each consisting of two bedrooms, a living room, a kitchen, and a bathroom, in order to provide safe and decent shelter for displaced families. Dr. Shamsan pointed out that BCFHFD is striving to implement more relief and humanitarian projects, in cooperation with its local and international partners, to alleviate the severity of the humanitarian crisis experienced by the people of Taizz Governorate. The handover ceremony was attended by Director General of Ma’afir district Adel Al-Mashmar, Director General of Legal Affairs in the Governorate Amin Fath, Director of the Executive Unit for Displaced Persons Ali Qa’id Al-Shamiri, Deputy Director General of the Social Affairs and Labor Office Dr. Mahmoud Al-Bakari, and Media Advisor to the Taizz Governorate Muhammad Marsh. With this contribution, Building Charity for Development Society embodies its strong commitment to supporting the displaced and affected, and emphasizes the importance of teamwork and cooperation between different parties to achieve such necessary humanitarian projects.

Dr. Al-Mikhlafi affirmed the local authority’s commitment, led by Governor Nabil Shamsan, to provide all necessary facilities to organizations working in the humanitarian field, in the belief of the importance of their role in alleviating the suffering of the displaced and those affected by the war.

For his part, Chairman of BCFHD Dr. Abdulkarim Shamsan explained that the project includes the construction of 20 housing units, each consisting of two bedrooms, a living room, a kitchen, and a bathroom, in order to provide safe and decent shelter for displaced families.

Dr. Shamsan pointed out that BCFHFD is striving to implement more relief and humanitarian projects, in cooperation with its local and international partners, to alleviate the severity of the humanitarian crisis experienced by the people of Taizz Governorate.

pages.title: Cholera Awareness Campaign in Taiz. – BCFHD
pages.summary: Cholera Awareness Campaign in Taiz
pages.content: Cholera Awareness Campaign in Taiz. An awareness radio episode was held as part of the “Cholera Awareness Campaign” in Taiz Governorate, to raise awareness among the community and improve health behavior to identify the causes of the outbreak, its symptoms, and ways to prevent it. Sponsored by Bena Charity for Human Development (BCFHD), the episode was broadcast on Watani FM, where Dr. Faten Al-Barkani, Deputy Director of the Health Education Department at the Health Office in the Governorate, was hosted. During the episode, Dr. Al-Barkani explained that cholera is a bacterial infection that affects the intestines and causes diarrhea and vomiting, and can lead to dehydration and death if not treated promptly. She stressed the importance of personal hygiene and washing hands with soap and water frequently, eating well-cooked food and drinking safe water, and avoiding eating from street vendors, as key ways to prevent cholera. She also urged citizens to seek immediate medical attention if any symptoms of cholera appear, such as diarrhea, vomiting, and fever. This campaign comes as part of the efforts to reduce the spread of cholera in Taiz Governorate and raise health awareness among the community.

pages.title: Beekeeping Training for Child Caregivers in Maqbana District. – BCFHD
pages.summary: Beekeeping Training for Child Caregivers in Maqbana District
pages.content: Beekeeping Training for Child Caregivers in Maqbana District. As part of the “integrated Response Project for Education and Protection Services for the Most Affected Children in Maqbanah District” project funded by Yemen Humanitarian Fund (YHF), Bena Charity (BCFHD) conducted a training for child caregivers on beekeeping. The training, which was attended by 6 males and 4 females on the first day, aimed to teach participants beekeeping skills, including: Hive assembly Managing bee colonies Honey harvesting Disease control The trainees will be provided with beehives in the next phase, which will enable them to start beekeeping as a means of improving their livelihoods. Beekeeping is a sustainable agricultural practice that can provide a source of income for poor families, especially in rural areas. Honeybee products, such as honey, also have high nutritional value and multiple health benefits. Through this project, BCFHD seeks to empower child caregivers to improve their living conditions and support their families.

pages.title: A ministerial Delegation Visits Bena Charity. – BCFHD
pages.summary: A ministerial Delegation Visits Bena Charity A ministerial delegation headed by Mr
pages.content: A ministerial Delegation Visits Bena Charity. A ministerial delegation headed by Mr. Saleh Mahmoud, Undersecretary of the Ministry of Social Affairs and Labor for the Social Care Sector, paid a visit to Bena Charity this morning. The delegation included Mr. Ihab Muhammad Ahmed, Director of the General Department of Social Defense in the Ministry, and Ms. Munia Al-Azzani, Assistant Director General of Assistance in the Ministry. Upon arrival at the headquarters of Bena Charity, the delegation was received by Mr. Tawfiq Abdulkhbir, Secretary-General of the Association, and Mr. Tariq Al-Hamadi, Executive Director. The Director General of the Social Affairs and Labor Office in the governorate and his deputy also attended the meeting. This visit aimed to strengthen cooperation between the Ministry of Social Affairs and Labor and Bena Charity in various development fields. The delegation inspected the workflow of Bena Charity’s departments and sections. Mr. Saleh Mahmoud, Undersecretary of the Ministry for the Social Care Sector, praised the great efforts made by Bena Charity in serving the community, stressing the ministry’s full support for the association’s activities and programs. He pointed out that the ministry is keen to strengthen partnership with civil society institutions, including development and charitable associations, to achieve social development goals.

pages.title: Distribution of the 7th round of cash incentives for volunteer teachers in Maqbana. – BCFHD
pages.summary: Distribution of the 7th round of cash incentives for volunteer teachers in Maqbana
pages.content: Distribution of the 7th round of cash incentives for volunteer teachers in Maqbana. Bena Charity, in partnership with Yemen Humanitarian Fund, distributed the 7th round of cash incentives for volunteer teachers in Maqbana district for May 2024. This distribution comes within the framework of the integrated Response Project for Education and Protection Services for the Most Affected Children in Maqbanah District, which aims to enhance children’s access to quality education in light of the difficult humanitarian conditions that Yemen is going through. The cash incentives include 8 rounds that are implemented throughout the project, and they benefit a group of volunteer teachers who make great efforts to deliver education to children in remote areas and areas affected by the conflict.

pages.title: Bena Charity Concludes Beekeeping and Honey Production Training Course. – BCFHD
pages.summary: Bena Charity Concludes Beekeeping and Honey Production Training Course
pages.content: Bena Charity Concludes Beekeeping and Honey Production Training Course. Bena Charity (BCFHD) today concluded a beekeeping and honey production training course for 40 participants from Al-Yaman Isolation, Al-Qahfah, and neighboring areas. The course, which was implemented within the Case Management activity of the “integrated Response Project for Education and Protection Services for the Most Affected Children in Maqbanah District”, funded by Yemen Humanitarian Fund (YHF), aimed to empower participants to acquire beekeeping and honey production skills, which will contribute to improving their livelihoods and creating new job opportunities for them. The trainees were distributed as follows: Al-Yemen Isolation: 17 trainees (7 from Al-Yemen and 10 from Al-Hajab Camp) Al-Qahfah and neighboring areas: 23 trainees Over the course of the training period, which lasted for several weeks, participants received theoretical and practical information on various aspects of beekeeping, including: Selecting an appropriate apiary site Types of beehives Methods of purchasing and bringing bee colonies Caring for and feeding bees Controlling bee diseases and enemies Extracting and processing honey Beekeeping tools and equipment will also be provided to the participants in the coming period to help them start their own projects. At the end of the course, the participants expressed their thanks and appreciation to Yemen Humanitarian Fund and Bena Charity for providing them with this opportunity to learn beekeeping, which will contribute to improving their lives and the lives of their families.

pages.title: Bena Charity Celebrates World Environment Day. – BCFHD
pages.summary: Bena Charity Celebrates World Environment Day Bena Charity celebrated World Environment Day this morning with the attendance of Secretary-General Mr Tawfiq Abdul-Khabir, Executive Director Mr
pages.content: Bena Charity Celebrates World Environment Day. Bena Charity celebrated World Environment Day this morning with the attendance of Secretary-General Mr. Tawfiq Abdul-Khabir, Executive Director Mr. Tariq Al-Hamadi, Head of the Environment and Climate Department Mr. Naseem Al-Muslimi, and BCFHD’s employees. Mr. Badri Al-Ibi, Director of the General Directorate of Environment and Climate in Taiz Governorate, stated that World Environment Day is a day led by the United Nations Environment Programme (UNEP) since 1973. World Environment Day is a global platform for raising public awareness about all aspects and issues of the natural and urban environment. Al-Ibi stressed that the global environment today is suffering from many issues, the most important of which are global warming and climate change, pollution of seas and oceans, air pollution, and increased pollution with waste, especially plastic waste, including pollution with chemicals and sewage waste. Al-Ibi noted that the deterioration of ecosystems and their biological components is a result of overexploitation and multiple pressures to increase the population, as well as a lack of a broad vision in protecting ecosystems, preserving biodiversity, and using them sustainably; which directly and indirectly affects the well-being of the population and economic development at the level of the globe. Mr. Tawfiq Abdul-Khabir, Secretary-General of Build Charity, affirmed the importance of preserving the environment, stressing that it is “an ethical and human responsibility that falls on everyone’s shoulders.” He pointed out that “the environmental challenges facing our planet require us to make more efforts to conserve natural resources and ensure a better future for future generations.” Abdul-Khabir explained that BCFHD “puts environmental protection at the top of its priorities.” He added, “We are working to implement many programs and projects that aim to spread environmental awareness, support sustainable practices, and strengthen cooperation between various stakeholders to protect the environment.” For his part, Mr. Naseem Al-Muslimi, Head of the Environment and Climate Department at BCFHD, affirmed BCFHD’s “commitment to providing technical and technical support to local communities to help protect the environment.” He pointed out that “BCFHD is working to develop programs that enhance and aim at the importance of preserving the environment.” This celebration comes as a confirmation of BCFHD’s commitment to protecting the environment and promoting sustainable development. BCFHD calls on all members of society to cooperate together to preserve our planet for future generations.

pages.title: OCHA Delegation Visits Taizz to Monitor Implementation of Water, Sanitation, and Hygiene Project for IDPs. – BCFHD
pages.summary: OCHA Delegation Visits Taizz to Monitor Implementation of Water, Sanitation, and Hygiene Project for IDPs
pages.content: OCHA Delegation Visits Taizz to Monitor Implementation of Water, Sanitation, and Hygiene Project for IDPs. A delegation from the United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) made a field visit to Taizz Governorate this morning to monitor the implementation of the “Provision of Comprehensive Emergency and Life-saving WASH Assistance to Vulnerable IDPs and Host Communities in Salh and Al Qahirah Districts – Taizz” project. The project is being implemented by BCFHD with funding from YHF. The delegation included Mr. Alaa Abdel Rab, OCHA Program and Monitoring Officer, and Ms. Amal Al-Aghbari, OCHA Humanitarian Officer (Turabah – Taizz). Also present were Eng. Sadiq Al-Tubai, Projects Director at the Local Water and Sanitation Corporation, Eng. Ali Al-Qabati, Wush Cluster Coordinator (Taizz and the West Coast), and Eng. Abdul Razzaq Al-Ashwal, Director of Operations at the Local Water Corporation. The delegation was received by Mr. Tawfiq Abdul Khabir, Secretary-General of BCFHD, Mr. Riyad Salam, Director of Programs at BCFHD, and Dr. Marwan Saeed, Project Director. During the visit, the delegation was briefed on: The progress of the project and the challenges facing implementation. The needs of IDPs and host communities in the field of water, sanitation, and hygiene. Discussions were held on ways to strengthen coordination and cooperation between OCHA and BCFHD to ensure the continued provision of essential services to IDPs and host communities. The OCHA delegation praised the efforts of BCFHD in implementing the project, stressing the importance of providing water, sanitation, and hygiene services to IDPs and host communities, especially in light of the difficult humanitarian conditions facing Yemen. This project is one of the important projects that contribute to improving the health conditions of IDPs and host communities in Taizz Governorate.

pages.title: Bena Charity Launches “Emergency Cholera Response” Activity in Taiz with UNICEF and YHF. – BCFHD
pages.summary: Bena Charity Launches “Emergency Cholera Response” Activity in Taiz with UNICEF and YHF
pages.content: Bena Charity Launches “Emergency Cholera Response” Activity in Taiz with UNICEF and YHF. Bena Charity has launched the “Emergency Cholera Response” activity in the Al-Mudafer, Al-Wazi’iyah, Muza, and Sabr Al-Muadim districts of Taiz Governorate, funded by UNICEF and supported by Yemen Humanitarian Fund. The activity aims to reduce the spread of cholera in these districts by raising awareness about disease prevention methods and distributing cholera kits and chlorine tablets. The activity targets 69 confirmed cholera cases with 20 contact families per case, for a total of 1,449 families. The activity includes 1,449 hygiene kits containing personal hygiene items, in addition to the distribution of chlorine tablets to homes affected by the cholera epidemic. BCFHD also organizes awareness campaigns on cholera prevention methods, including the distribution of posters and brochures.

pages.title: OCHA delegation continues to visit Bena’s projects in Taizz. – BCFHD
pages.summary: OCHA delegation continues to visit Bena’s projects in Taizz A delegation from the United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA), represented by Mr
pages.content: OCHA delegation continues to visit Bena’s projects in Taizz. A delegation from the United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA), represented by Mr. Alaa Abdel Rab, Program and Monitoring Officer, continued its field visits to projects implemented by Bena in Taizz Governorate. The visit targeted the “integrated Response Project for Education and Protection Services for the Most Affected Children in Maqbanah District”, funded by Yemen Humanitarian Fund (YHF). During the visit, the delegation was briefed on the progress of the project and the services it provides to the beneficiary children, including: Education: Providing quality educational opportunities for children and providing them with psychosocial support. Protection: Providing protection services for children at risk, such as violence, exploitation and neglect. Psychosocial support: Providing psychosocial support for children affected by the conflict. The delegation also met with some of the project beneficiaries and listened to their testimonies about the impact of the project on their lives. The delegation expressed its appreciation for BCFHD’s efforts in implementing this important project, which contributes to improving the lives of children in Maqbana District. This visit comes within the framework of OCHA’s keenness to follow up on the progress of humanitarian projects and ensure that aid reaches those who deserve it. It is also an opportunity to strengthen the partnership between OCHA and BCFHD and to work on expanding the scope of cooperation in the future.

pages.title: Building Schools in Remote Areas: An Investment in a Bright Future! – BCFHD
pages.summary: Building Schools in Remote Areas: An Investment in a Bright Future Education is the cornerstone of nation-building and progress, and a fundamental pillar for achieving sustainable development
pages.content: Building Schools in Remote Areas: An Investment in a Bright Future! Education is the cornerstone of nation-building and progress, and a fundamental pillar for achieving sustainable development. At Bena Charity, we firmly believe in the importance of building schools and classrooms in remote areas, as we believe it is a real investment in a bright future for generations to come. The Importance of Building Schools in Remote Areas: – Breaking the Cycle of Poverty: Education is an effective tool for breaking the cycle of poverty, as it empowers individuals to acquire the skills and knowledge needed to obtain better job opportunities and improve their living standards. – Promoting Community Development: Schools play a vital role in promoting community development by providing a safe and stimulating learning environment that contributes to the development of individuals’ skills and abilities, and helps prepare a conscious generation capable of contributing to the building of their community. – Reducing Dropout Rates: Schools located close to students’ homes help reduce dropout rates, especially among girls, allowing them to access better education and helping improve their lives. – Integrating Everyone into the Educational Process: Schools in remote areas ensure that all children, regardless of their background or place of residence, have access to quality education, which contributes to achieving the principle of equal opportunities. – Preparing an Educated Generation: Schools in remote areas contribute to the preparation of an educated generation capable of keeping pace with scientific and technological developments and effectively participating in building the renaissance of their country. Based on our belief in the importance of education, Bena Charity pays great attention to supporting the construction of schools and classrooms in remote areas. We strive to provide a suitable learning environment for all children, regardless of their place of residence or their social and economic circumstances.

pages.title: Bena Charity Distributes Cash Incentives to Volunteer Teachers in Its Eighth and Final Round. – BCFHD
pages.summary: Bena Charity Distributes Cash Incentives to Volunteer Teachers in Its Eighth and Final Round
pages.content: Bena Charity Distributes Cash Incentives to Volunteer Teachers in Its Eighth and Final Round. In its ongoing efforts to support education, Bena Charity for Human Development (BCFHD) today, Wednesday, distributed cash incentives to volunteer teachers in its eighth round for June 2024. This support for volunteer teachers comes as part of the “integrated Response Project for Education and Protection Services for the Most Affected Children in Maqbanah District”, project, which is implemented with funding from Yemen Humanitarian Fund (YHF). The project aims to ensure that children have access to quality education in a safe environment by supporting teachers and providing the necessary educational tools and materials. Cash incentives were distributed to volunteer teachers in appreciation of their efforts in educating children despite the difficult circumstances. This eighth round is the final round of distributions, as BCFHD reaffirms its commitment to supporting education in Yemen in general and Taiz in particular, in light of the difficult conditions the country is going through.
