pages.title: Achievement Brings Smiles to Faces of Hamir Village Residents: Rehabilitation and Paved Roads Connecting the Mountain and Valley. – BCFHD
pages.summary: Achievement Brings Smiles to Faces of Hamir Village Residents: Rehabilitation and Paved Roads Connecting the Mountain and Valley
pages.content: Achievement Brings Smiles to Faces of Hamir Village Residents: Rehabilitation and Paved Roads Connecting the Mountain and Valley. In a joyful ceremony, Bani Hamir Isolation in Maqbana District, Taiz Governorate, celebrated the handover of the Hamir Mountain Village Road Rehabilitation and Paving Project and the Hamir Valley Village Road. This achievement is the fruit of fruitful cooperation between BCFHD and Oxfam, within the framework of the “Building Resilience Through Integrated Community-Based and Humanitarian Systems Transformation and Leadership in Yemen” project in Al Ma’afir and Maqbana Districts in Taiz Governorate. The project was implemented through the “Cash for Work” activity with the participation of 180 beneficiaries from the residents of Hamir Al Jabal and Hamir Al Wadi villages, during the period from December 2023 to May 2024. The project included works that included: Leveling the targeted roads with a length of 930 meters. Paving the most rugged sections with a length of 680 meters. Building retaining walls with a volume of 110 cubic meters. The spirit of cooperation between Oxfam, BCFHD, and the local community was embodied in the completion of this vital project, which will contribute significantly to improving the lives of the residents of Hamir village, facilitating movement between its various parts, and strengthening communication between them. In order to ensure the sustainability of this achievement, the project was handed over to community committees for permanent supervision and continuous maintenance. The committees were also provided with the tools of the “Cash for Work” activity to enable them to benefit from them in maintaining the project and any other projects or initiatives that serve the public interest. The handover ceremony was attended by: Mr. Hamid Al-Khulidi, Director of Maqbana Directorate. Mr. Tawfiq Abdel Khabir, Secretary-General of BCFHD. Engineer Zaher Al-Yousfi, Project Officer. Mr. Shahab Abdul Halim, Project Logistics. Engineer Nabil Al-Hamairi, Supervising Engineer. Members of community committees in the beneficiary villages. Some of the beneficiary citizens. The residents of Hamir village expressed their deep gratitude to BCFHD and Oxfam for this great achievement that will change their lives for the better. This project was a shining model of community work and proved that cooperation between different parties, led by the local community, can bring about tangible positive changes on the ground.

pages.title: Bena Charity Conducts Training Course for Employees on “AI Tools”. – BCFHD
pages.summary: Bena Charity Conducts Training Course for Employees on “AI Tools” Bena Charity organized a training course for its employees this morning on “Employing AI Tools in Humanitarian Work
pages.content: Bena Charity Conducts Training Course for Employees on “AI Tools”. Bena Charity organized a training course for its employees this morning on “Employing AI Tools in Humanitarian Work.” The course aimed to introduce employees to the latest AI technologies and how to benefit from them to improve the efficiency of humanitarian work. The course was presented by Professor Ammar Qaid, who explained to the participants the importance of AI in humanitarian work and presented a number of examples of its practical applications. He also gave the participants an overview of the available AI tools and how to use them in various fields of humanitarian work. This training course comes as part of BCFHD’s ongoing efforts to build the capacity of its employees and enable them to benefit from these technologies effectively.

pages.title: Our growing population! – BCFHD
pages.summary: Our growing population The world’s population is more than three times larger than it was in the mid-twentieth century The global human population reached 8
pages.content: Our growing population! The world’s population is more than three times larger than it was in the mid-twentieth century. The global human population reached 8.0 billion in mid-November 2022 from an estimated 2.5 billion people in 1950, adding 1 billion people since 2010 and 2 billion since 1998. The world’s population is expected to increase by nearly 2 billion persons in the next 30 years, from the current 8 billion to 9.7 billion in 2050 and could peak at nearly 10.4 billion in the mid-2080s.

pages.title: Bena Charity Society Delivers 70 Cleaning Boxes to the Cleaning and Improvement Fund in Taiz. – BCFHD
pages.summary: Bena Charity Society Delivers 70 Cleaning Boxes to the Cleaning and Improvement Fund in Taiz
pages.content: Bena Charity Society Delivers 70 Cleaning Boxes to the Cleaning and Improvement Fund in Taiz. Funded by Yemen Humanitarian Fund, Bena Charity has implemented the activity “Delivering 70 cleaning boxes to the Cleaning and Improvement Fund in Taiz Governorate”. This activity comes within the project “Provision of Comprehensive Emergency and Life-saving WASH Assistance to Vulnerable IDPs and Host Communities in Salh and Al Qahirah Districts – Taizz”. The delivery was attended by a number of officials, including: Dr. Iftihan Al-Mashahari, Director of the Cleaning and Improvement Fund. Mr. Ali Al-Shamiri, Director of the Executive Unit in the Governorate. Mr. Abdul Wahid Al-Azzani, Deputy Director of the Social Affairs and Labor Office in the Governorate. Mr. Najib Abdullah, Deputy Director of the Planning and International Cooperation Office in the Governorate. Mr. Aziz Jamel, Director of the Cleaning and Improvement Fund in Cairo Directorate. Mr. Mohammed Amer, Director of the Executive Unit Management in Cairo Directorate. Mr. Abdul Alim Al-Solwi, Chairman of the 100-Day Challenge Initiative. Also in attendance were: Dr. Abdul Karim Shamsan, President of BCFHD. Mr. Tariq Al-Hamadi, Director of BCFHD. Dr. Marwan Saeed, Project Manager at BCFHD. This project aims to improve sanitation services in Salh and Al Qahirah Districts, reduce the spread of communicable diseases, and create a suitable healthy environment for displaced persons and host communities. This initiative is an important step towards improving the living conditions of the people in Taiz Governorate, especially in light of the humanitarian crisis the country is experiencing.

pages.title: Bena Charity Hands Over 3 Water and Sanitation Projects in Taiz. – BCFHD
pages.summary: Bena Charity Hands Over 3 Water and Sanitation Projects in Taiz Bena Charity today handed over three important water and sanitation projects to the local water and sanitation authority
pages.content: Bena Charity Hands Over 3 Water and Sanitation Projects in Taiz. Bena Charity today handed over three important water and sanitation projects to the local water and sanitation authority. The projects include: – Al-Qammat and Al-Askari Water Network: The network has been rehabilitated to provide safe drinking water to residents of the two areas. The project involved 390 household connections and 465 meters of new pipeline. – Al-Jahmaliyah Sewerage Network: The damaged network has been replaced with a new 124-meter sewer line, including 5 manholes, 9 inspection chambers, and connection to the main line. – Al-Rawda Water Network: The network has been rehabilitated to provide water to residents of the area. The project involved 130 household connections and 230 meters of new pipeline. The projects also included the installation of a number of valves and air vents. These projects are part of the “Provision of Comprehensive Emergency and Life-saving WASH Assistance to Vulnerable IDPs and Host Communities in Salh and Al Qahirah Districts – Taiz” project, implemented by BCFHD with funding from Yemen Humanitarian Fund. The handover ceremony was attended by: Eng. Arif Alyousifi: Director of Salalah Directorate Eng. Sadek Al-Tabai: Project Manager of the Local Water and Sanitation Authority Dr. Abdul Karim Shamsan: Chairman of BCFHD Mr. Abdul Latif Al-Bawashari: Advisor to the Director of Cairo Directorate Mr. Mohammed Amer: Director of the Executive Unit in Cairo Directorate Mr. Ahmed Ghaleb: Director of the Executive Unit in Salalah Directorate These projects are of great importance to the residents of Salalah and Cairo Directorates, as they will contribute to: – Improving access to safe water for residents – Effectively treating wastewater – Reducing the spread of waterborne diseases – Improving the overall health environment – Dr. AbdullKarim Shamsan, Chairman of BCFHD, stressed the importance of cooperation between humanitarian organizations and local institutions to implement projects that meet the needs of affected communities. He praised the support of Yemen Humanitarian Fund, which contributed to the completion of these important projects. For his part, Eng. Sadek Al-Tubai, Project Manager of the Local Water and Sanitation Authority, praised the efforts of BCFHD in implementing these projects, reaffirming the authority’s commitment to maintaining these projects and ensuring their continued service to the population. These projects come within the framework of efforts to alleviate the suffering of the population affected by the conflict in Yemen, and to improve their living and health conditions.

The projects include: – Al-Qammat and Al-Askari Water Network: The network has been rehabilitated to provide safe drinking water to residents of the two areas. The project involved 390 household connections and 465 meters of new pipeline. – Al-Jahmaliyah Sewerage Network: The damaged network has been replaced with a new 124-meter sewer line, including 5 manholes, 9 inspection chambers, and connection to the main line. – Al-Rawda Water Network: The network has been rehabilitated to provide water to residents of the area. The project involved 130 household connections and 230 meters of new pipeline. The projects also included the installation of a number of valves and air vents. These projects are part of the “Provision of Comprehensive Emergency and Life-saving WASH Assistance to Vulnerable IDPs and Host Communities in Salh and Al Qahirah Districts – Taiz” project, implemented by BCFHD with funding from Yemen Humanitarian Fund. The handover ceremony was attended by: Eng. Arif Alyousifi: Director of Salalah Directorate Eng. Sadek Al-Tabai: Project Manager of the Local Water and Sanitation Authority Dr. Abdul Karim Shamsan: Chairman of BCFHD Mr. Abdul Latif Al-Bawashari: Advisor to the Director of Cairo Directorate Mr. Mohammed Amer: Director of the Executive Unit in Cairo Directorate Mr. Ahmed Ghaleb: Director of the Executive Unit in Salalah Directorate These projects are of great importance to the residents of Salalah and Cairo Directorates, as they will contribute to: – Improving access to safe water for residents – Effectively treating wastewater – Reducing the spread of waterborne diseases – Improving the overall health environment – Dr. AbdullKarim Shamsan, Chairman of BCFHD, stressed the importance of cooperation between humanitarian organizations and local institutions to implement projects that meet the needs of affected communities. He praised the support of Yemen Humanitarian Fund, which contributed to the completion of these important projects. For his part, Eng. Sadek Al-Tubai, Project Manager of the Local Water and Sanitation Authority, praised the efforts of BCFHD in implementing these projects, reaffirming the authority’s commitment to maintaining these projects and ensuring their continued service to the population. These projects come within the framework of efforts to alleviate the suffering of the population affected by the conflict in Yemen, and to improve their living and health conditions.

pages.title: BCFHD Board Holds Regular Meeting to Discuss a Range of Topics. – BCFHD
pages.summary: BCFHD Board Holds Regular Meeting to Discuss a Range of Topics The Board of Directors of the BCFHD, chaired by Dr
pages.content: BCFHD Board Holds Regular Meeting to Discuss a Range of Topics. The Board of Directors of the BCFHD, chaired by Dr. Abdul Karim Shamsan, held its regular meeting on Wednesday, July 17, 2024, at BCFHD’s headquarters. All members of the Board of Directors were present. The meeting discussed a number of topics and issues on the agenda, including: Approval of the minutes of the previous meeting and review of the semi-annual administrative and financial reports, which included a detailed presentation of BCFHD’s activities during the past six months, as well as BCFHD’s financial status. The Board of Directors discussed the reports submitted, made its observations and inquiries, and raised a number of other topics and issues related to BCFHD’s work. These were discussed in detail and appropriate decisions were taken. The meeting concluded with the members of the Board of Directors emphasizing the importance of continuing to work hard to achieve BCFHD’s goals and strengthen its role in the community.

pages.title: 66 Caregivers of Children at Risk of Protection Benefit from Goats Distribution Activity in Maqbana District. – BCFHD
pages.summary: 66 Caregivers of Children at Risk of Protection Benefit from Goats Distribution Activity in Maqbana District
pages.content: 66 Caregivers of Children at Risk of Protection Benefit from Goats Distribution Activity in Maqbana District. As part of its efforts to provide support to the most needy families in Maqbana District, Bena Charity distributed empowerment units (Goats) to 66 caregivers, within the case management activity of “integrated Response Project for Education and Protection Services for the Most Affected Children in Maqbanah District”, which is implemented with the support of Yemen Humanitarian Fund. The distribution included 16 men and 50 women from AL-Yamen and Qahafa isolations and the surrounding areas. The empowerment units were represented in the distribution of Goats to caregivers of vulnerable children, with the aim of enabling them to provide a sustainable source of income that contributes to improving their living standards and caring for their children. Through this project, Bena Charity seeks to strengthen the resilience of local communities and mitigate the negative effects of the conflict on children and the most vulnerable families.

pages.title: 28 July is World Hepatitis Day! – BCFHD
pages.summary: 28 July is World Hepatitis Day
pages.content: 28 July is World Hepatitis Day! World Hepatitis Day, 28 July, is an opportunity to step up national and international efforts on hepatitis, encourage actions and engagement by individuals, partners and the public and highlight the need for a greater global response as outlined in the WHO’s Global hepatitis report of 2017. The date of 28 July was chosen because it is the birthday of Nobel-prize winning scientist Dr Baruch Blumberg, who discovered hepatitis B virus (HBV) and developed a diagnostic test and vaccine for the virus. Low coverage of testing and treatment is the most important gap to be addressed in order to achieve the global elimination goals by 2030.

pages.title: Bena Charity Empowers Board Members with Decision-Making and Problem-Solving Skills. – BCFHD
pages.summary: Bena Charity Empowers Board Members with Decision-Making and Problem-Solving Skills
pages.content: Bena Charity Empowers Board Members with Decision-Making and Problem-Solving Skills. In a strategic move to enhance institutional capacity, Bena Charity organized a specialized training course for its board members, focusing on the latest methods and techniques in decision-making and problem-solving. Facilitated by Mr. Kamil Al Nizari, the course aimed to equip board members with the necessary tools and knowledge to make sound and decisive decisions, aligning with BCFHD’s vision and humanitarian mission. “At Bena Charity, we believe in investing in human capital development, especially our board members who form the backbone of our organization,” said BCFHD’s Secretary-General, Mr. Tawfiq Abdul Khabeer. “This course is part of our ongoing efforts to enhance BCFHD’s performance and make the most of our available resources.” Bena Charity remains steadfast in its commitment to developing its staff’s capabilities. Organizing such courses is part of a series of training programs aimed at building a strong and cohesive team dedicated to serving the community.

pages.title: Bena Charity Organizes Training Course to Empower Community Committees. – BCFHD
pages.summary: Bena Charity Organizes Training Course to Empower Community Committees
pages.content: Bena Charity Organizes Training Course to Empower Community Committees. The Women and Child Protection Sector at Bena Charity has organized an intensive training course on “Fundamentals of Fieldwork for Community Committees”. The aim of this course is to enhance the capacity of community committees operating in the directorates of Al-Muzaffar, Salah, and Al-Qahira, and to empower them to serve their local communities. A large number of female members of community committees participated in the course. They received theoretical and practical training on a range of essential skills, including: Identifying community needs Project planning and implementation Resource management Research and communication Conflict resolution At the conclusion of the course, the participants expressed their satisfaction with the valuable information they had acquired, emphasizing the importance of such courses in developing their skills and empowering them to contribute effectively to the development of their communities.

pages.title: From Clicks to Progress: Youth Digital Pathways for Sustainable Development! – BCFHD
pages.summary: From Clicks to Progress: Youth Digital Pathways for Sustainable Development Digitalization is transforming our world, offering unprecedented opportunities to accelerate sustainable development
pages.content: From Clicks to Progress: Youth Digital Pathways for Sustainable Development! Digitalization is transforming our world, offering unprecedented opportunities to accelerate sustainable development. Digital technologies such as mobile devices, services, and artificial intelligence are instrumental in advancing the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). Data generated from digital interactions supports evidence-based decision-making. With profound impact across economic, social and environmental dimensions, digital technologies and data contribute to at least 70 per cent of the 169 SDG targets while potentially reducing the cost of achieving these goals by up to USD 55 trillion. Young people are leading the charge in digital adoption and innovation, with three-quarters of those aged 15 to 24 using the internet in 2022, a rate higher than other age groups. However, disparities persist, particularly in low-income countries and among young women, who often have less access to the internet and digital skills compared to their male counterparts. While there is an urgent need to enhance digital inclusion, youth are largely recognized as “digital natives,” using technology to drive change and create solutions. As the 2030 deadline for the SDGs approaches, the role of young people in digital innovation is essential for addressing global issues. By celebrating the digital contributions of youth, we can inspire further innovation and collaboration towards achieving sustainable development.

pages.title: World Humanitarian Day 2024! – BCFHD
pages.summary: World Humanitarian Day 2024 2023 was the deadliest year on record for humanitarian workers 2024 could be even worse
pages.content: World Humanitarian Day 2024! 2023 was the deadliest year on record for humanitarian workers. 2024 could be even worse. These facts lay bare a glaring truth: the world is failing humanitarian workers and, by extension, the people they serve. Despite universally accepted international laws to regulate the conduct of armed conflict and limit its impact, violations of these laws continue unabated, unchallenged and unchecked. And while civilians, including aid workers, pay the ultimate price, the perpetrators continue to evade justice. This failure of those in power cannot be allowed to continue. Attacks on humanitarian workers and humanitarian assets must stop. Attacks on civilians and civilian infrastructure must stop. This World Humanitarian Day, we demand an end to these violations and the impunity with which they are committed. It is time for those in power to end impunity and #ActForHumanity. Issued by the United Nations on World Humanitarian Day.

pages.title: Training Courses Conclude to Enhance Water Resource Management and Conflict Resolution in Taiz and Hodeidah. – BCFHD
pages.summary: Training Courses Conclude to Enhance Water Resource Management and Conflict Resolution in Taiz and Hodeidah
pages.content: Training Courses Conclude to Enhance Water Resource Management and Conflict Resolution in Taiz and Hodeidah. Intensive training courses organized by Bena Charity Humanitarian Development (BCFHD), in partnership with International Organization for Migration (IOM) and with support of the KfW Development Bank, concluded today, Wednesday, as part of the “Project of Enhancing Water Resource Management in IDP Communities in South Ta’iz” project. The courses targeted 60 members of community water management committees and 30 members of conflict resolution committees in Al Mukha Directorate, Taiz City Directorates, and Hays Directorate in Hodeidah Governorate. The courses covered vital topics such as integrated water resources management, flood irrigation management, climate change, and the development of community water management plans. In addition, conflict resolution committees were trained on developing internal rules and regulations for community resource centers, conflict management, community dialogue, and mediation. This project aims to enhance the capacity of local communities to sustainably manage their water resources and resolve water-related conflicts, contributing to improved livelihoods and stability in the targeted areas.

pages.title: Bena Charity Delivers Three New Classrooms to Maqbana District. – BCFHD
pages.summary: Bena Charity Delivers Three New Classrooms to Maqbana District
pages.content: Bena Charity Delivers Three New Classrooms to Maqbana District. In a demonstration of its commitment to education and providing suitable learning environments for children, Bena Charity for Humanitarian Development today handed over three fully equipped classrooms to the Education Office and local authorities in Maqbana District. These classrooms are part of the “integrated Response Project for Education and Protection Services for the Most Affected Children in Maqbanah District” project, funded by Yemen Humanitarian Fund. The newly constructed and equipped classrooms feature modern facilities that contribute to improving the learning process, including desks, whiteboards, and a solar power system, as well as a well-equipped sanitary facility. The handover ceremony was attended by several officials, as well as the project team, social figures, and local residents.

pages.title: International Literacy Day! – BCFHD
pages.summary: International Literacy Day Literacy is a fundamental human right for all It opens the door to the enjoyment of other human rights, greater freedoms, and global citizenship
pages.content: International Literacy Day! Literacy is a fundamental human right for all. It opens the door to the enjoyment of other human rights, greater freedoms, and global citizenship. Literacy is a foundation for people to acquire broader knowledge, skills, values, attitudes, and behaviours to foster a culture of lasting peace based on respect for equality and non-discrimination, the rule of law, solidarity, justice, diversity, and tolerance and to build harmonious relations with oneself, other people and the planet. In 2022, however, at least one out of seven adults aged 15 and above (754 million) lacked basic literacy skills. Additionally, millions of children are struggling to acquire minimum levels of proficiency in reading, writing and numeracy, while some 250 million children of 6-18 years old are out of school. – Issued by UNESCO on the # International _ Literacy _ Day ✍ 🏼

pages.title: On the occasion of the #InternationalDaytoProtectEducationfromAttack.. – BCFHD
pages.summary: On the occasion of the #InternationalDaytoProtectEducationfromAttack Places of education should be safe havens for children, students and education personnel
pages.content: On the occasion of the #InternationalDaytoProtectEducationfromAttack.. Places of education should be safe havens for children, students and education personnel. However, all too often they, and the places wherein they learn, become either direct targets or collateral damage in conflict-affected contexts. Attacks on education can have serious, long-term physical and psychological repercussions for students and teachers. Attacks can suspend teaching and learning, lead to a significant increase in dropout rates and prevent students from accessing their right to quality education.

pages.title: Bena Charity Opens Bilal bin Rabah and Al-Azhar Schools in Maqbna. – BCFHD
pages.summary: Bena Charity Opens Bilal bin Rabah and Al-Azhar Schools in Maqbna
pages.content: Bena Charity Opens Bilal bin Rabah and Al-Azhar Schools in Maqbna. In a significant step to enhance educational opportunities for children in Maqbna District, Bilal bin Rabah and Al-Azhar Schools have been opened after construction, furnishing, and equipping them with sanitary facilities. This achievement comes as part of the “integrated Response Project for Education and Protection Services for the Most Affected Children in Maqbanah District”, implemented by Bena Charity for Human Development with funding from Yemen Humanitarian Fund, under the generous patronage of the Governor of the Governorate, Mr. Nabil Shamsan, Under the supervision of the Provincial Education Office and the local authority in Maqbna District. Bilal Bin Rabah School saw the construction and furnishing of six classrooms equipped with modern seating and plates, as well as the installation of solar power systems to provide electricity, and the equipping of three sanitation facilities. The Al-Zahar School in Al-Qashah, Three classrooms have been built and furnished, with solar power systems and two health facilities installed.. This project aims to provide a safe and equipped learning environment for children in Maqbna, especially the most affected, and to meet their basic educational needs. It also contributes to increasing access to education and improving its quality, thus contributing to building a better future for future generations. The opening was widely attended by local officials, educators, parents, and students.

pages.title: World Patient Safety Day 2024! – BCFHD
pages.summary: World Patient Safety Day 2024 A diagnosis identifies a patient’s health problem
pages.content: World Patient Safety Day 2024! A diagnosis identifies a patient’s health problem. To reach a diagnosis, patients and their health care teams must work together to navigate the complex and sometimes lengthy diagnostic process. It involves discussion with the patient, examination, testing and review of results before reaching the final diagnosis and treatment. Errors can occur at any stage and can have significant consequences. Delayed, incorrect or missed diagnosis can prolong illness and sometimes cause disability or even death. The theme for this year’s World Patient Safety Day’s is focused on improving diagnosis for patient safety, using the slogan “Get it right, make it safe!”. On the day, patients and families, health workers, health care leaders, policy makers and civil society will emphasize the pivotal role of correct and timely diagnosis in improving patient safety.

pages.title: International Day of Peace 2024! – BCFHD
pages.summary: International Day of Peace 2024 We celebrate the International Day of Peace and commemorate the 25th anniversary of the adoption of the Declaration and Programme of Action on a Culture of Peace
pages.content: International Day of Peace 2024! We celebrate the International Day of Peace and commemorate the 25th anniversary of the adoption of the Declaration and Programme of Action on a Culture of Peace. At BCFHD, we believe that peace is not merely the absence of war, but a state of harmony and concord among individuals and peoples. Let’s work together to build communities based on mutual respect, dialogue, and cooperation. Let’s cultivate a culture of peace in the hearts of our children and youth, so we can reap generations that live in peace and prosperity. #InternationalDayofPeace

pages.title: Ageing with Dignity: The Importance of Strengthening Care and Support Systems for Older Persons Worldwide! – BCFHD
pages.summary: Ageing with Dignity: The Importance of Strengthening Care and Support Systems for Older Persons Worldwide Population ageing is a major global trend reshaping societies worldwide
pages.content: Ageing with Dignity: The Importance of Strengthening Care and Support Systems for Older Persons Worldwide! Population ageing is a major global trend reshaping societies worldwide. Life expectancy at birth now exceeds 75 years in half of the world’s countries, 25 years longer than in 1950. By 2030, older persons are projected to outnumber youth globally, with this increase most rapid in developing countries. This demographic shift has significantly transformed the caregiving landscape, encompassing a wide range of needs for both paid and unpaid support in formal and informal settings. As populations age, the demand for comprehensive healthcare, care, and social support services has grown substantially, particularly for older persons with conditions such as dementia. In recognition of these challenges and opportunities, the 34th commemoration of the United Nations International Day of Older Persons will focus on the theme of “Ageing with Dignity: The Importance of Strengthening Care and Support Systems for Older Persons Worldwide”. This year’s event will bring together experts to discuss policies, legislation, and practices that strengthen care and support systems for older persons. It will highlight the urgent need to expand training and educational opportunities in geriatrics and gerontology, address the global shortage of care workers, and recognize the diverse contributions of caregivers. The commemoration will also emphasize the importance of protecting the human rights of both caregivers and care recipients, promoting person-centered approaches to care that respect the dignity, beliefs, needs, and privacy of older persons, and for the right to make decisions about their care and quality of their lives. – Issued by the United Nations on #InternationalDayofOlderPersons 10 – Oct – 2024

headings.text: Ageing with Dignity: The Importance of Strengthening Care and Support Systems for Older Persons Worldwide!

paragraphs: Population ageing is a major global trend reshaping societies worldwide. Life expectancy at birth now exceeds 75 years in half of the world’s countries, 25 years longer than in 1950. By 2030, older persons are projected to outnumber youth globally, with this increase most rapid in developing countries. This demographic shift has significantly transformed the caregiving landscape, encompassing a wide range of needs for both paid and unpaid support in formal and informal settings. As populations age, the demand for comprehensive healthcare, care, and social support services has grown substantially, particularly for older persons with conditions such as dementia. In recognition of these challenges and opportunities, the 34th commemoration of the United Nations International Day of Older Persons will focus on the theme of “Ageing with Dignity: The Importance of Strengthening Care and Support Systems for Older Persons Worldwide”.

This year’s event will bring together experts to discuss policies, legislation, and practices that strengthen care and support systems for older persons. It will highlight the urgent need to expand training and educational opportunities in geriatrics and gerontology, address the global shortage of care workers, and recognize the diverse contributions of caregivers. The commemoration will also emphasize the importance of protecting the human rights of both caregivers and care recipients, promoting person-centered approaches to care that respect the dignity, beliefs, needs, and privacy of older persons, and for the right to make decisions about their care and quality of their lives.
– Issued by the United Nations on #InternationalDayofOlderPersons 10 – Oct – 2024

pages.title: World Teachers’ Day! – BCFHD
pages.summary: World Teachers’ Day eachers play a pivotal role in shaping the future by nurturing students and driving educational progress
pages.content: World Teachers’ Day! eachers play a pivotal role in shaping the future by nurturing students and driving educational progress. However, to fully harness their potential, it’s crucial that their voices are heard and valued in the decision-making processes that affect their profession. This year’s World Teachers’ Day highlights the need to address the systemic challenges teachers face and to establish a more inclusive dialogue about their role in education. The 2024 celebrations will focus on “Valuing teacher voices: towards a new social contract for education”, underscoring the urgency of calling for and attending to teachers’ voices to address their challenges but, most importantly, to acknowledge and benefit from the expert knowledge and input that they bring to education. – صادر عن اليونسكو | Issued by UNESCO

pages.title: World Mental Health Day! – BCFHD
pages.summary: World Mental Health Day On World Mental Health Day, Bena Charity for Human Development emphasizes the importance of mental health as a fundamental pillar of individual and societal happiness
pages.content: World Mental Health Day! On World Mental Health Day, Bena Charity for Human Development emphasizes the importance of mental health as a fundamental pillar of individual and societal happiness. Mental health is not a luxury, but a basic right for every human being, guiding us towards a healthy and balanced life. At Bena Charity, we recognize the magnitude of the challenges facing mental health in our modern world, where millions of people suffer from mental disorders that negatively impact their daily lives and social relationships. Therefore, we call for collective efforts to address these challenges and provide the necessary support to those who are struggling. Undeniable Facts: * Mental health issues place a significant burden on societies, preventing millions of individuals from reaching their full potential. * Young people and adolescents, in particular, are experiencing a rise in mental health disorders, requiring special attention to this group. * Many mental health problems can be prevented, and mental well-being can be promoted through healthy lifestyle choices, regular exercise, avoiding stress, and seeking social support. Our Goals on this Day: – Raising awareness of the importance of mental health and changing the societal stigma associated with mental illnesses. – Encouraging and supporting individuals to seek help when needed, and providing specialized mental health services. – Collaborating with government institutions and non-profit organizations to develop programs and policies that enhance mental health in society. We invite everyone to work together to build a healthier and happier community. Mental health is a shared responsibility that falls on all of us.

pages.title: A workshop under the theme “Girls’ Vision for the Future” – BCFHD
pages.summary: A workshop under the theme “Girls’ Vision for the Future” This morning, a workshop was held under the theme “Girls’ Vision for the Future,” organized by the Women’s and Children’s Protection...
pages.content: A workshop under the theme “Girls’ Vision for the Future” This morning, a workshop was held under the theme “Girls’ Vision for the Future,” organized by the Women’s and Children’s Protection Sector of BCFHD. The workshop discussed the importance of girls’ education, coinciding with the International Day of the Girl, which falls tomorrow, Friday, October 11, 2024. The workshop aimed to raise awareness about the importance of educating girls and developing their skills to enable them to face future challenges and actively participate in community development.

pages.title: Congratulations to Brother Abdulaziz Saif on Obtaining His Master’s Degree. – BCFHD
pages.summary: Congratulations to Brother Abdulaziz Saif on Obtaining His Master’s Degree
pages.content: Congratulations to Brother Abdulaziz Saif on Obtaining His Master’s Degree. Bena Charity for Human Development (BCFHD) extends its heartfelt congratulations and best wishes to our dear brother, Abdulaziz Saif Mohammed Qaed, the Logistics Manager at BCFHD, on his achievement of a Master’s degree in Business Administration with honors. At BCFHD, we take pride in your accomplishments and highly value your efforts and dedication in serving the community and advancing the path of human development. Your presence in our team is of great value, and we look forward to your continued contributions and exceptional leadership in a promising future. Once again, we congratulate you on this achievement and wish you continued success and prosperity in your professional and academic journey. Best regards, Management and staff of BCFHD.

pages.title: World Food Day 2024 – BCFHD
pages.summary: World Food Day 2024 Did you know that the world produces enough food to feed everyone and more Yet, 733 million people suffer from hunger
pages.content: World Food Day 2024 Did you know that the world produces enough food to feed everyone and more? Yet, 733 million people suffer from hunger! This unfortunate reality reflects the magnitude of the challenges we face, from conflicts and climate shocks to inequality. Hunger is a global problem that requires global solutions. Together, we can contribute to ending hunger by: Supporting small-scale farmers. Fighting climate change. Reducing food loss and waste. Raising awareness about the importance of healthy diets. Food is a basic human right, and it’s not just a need but the foundation of life and well-being.

pages.title: Ending Social and Institutional Maltreatment Acting together for just, peaceful and inclusive societies. – BCFHD
pages.summary: Ending Social and Institutional Maltreatment Acting together for just, peaceful and inclusive societies Poverty has multiple dimensions, some visible and others hidden, but all interlinked
pages.content: Ending Social and Institutional Maltreatment Acting together for just, peaceful and inclusive societies. Poverty has multiple dimensions, some visible and others hidden, but all interlinked. This year’s theme will highlight one of the Hidden Dimension of Poverty the social and institutional maltreatment experienced by people living in poverty. People living in poverty face negative attitudes. They are stigmatized, discriminated against, judged for example by their appearance, accent, address – or lack of it, blamed for their situation, and treated with disrespect. Social maltreatment creates a setting for institutional maltreatment, with a combination of negative attitudes, like mistrust and disrespect, as well as controlling discriminatory policies and practices, denying people of their fundamental human rights, for example, access to healthcare, education, housing, and the right to legal identity. Social and institutional maltreatment interact and amplify each other, fueling this double-edged violence and deepening the injustice. A meaningful understanding of poverty and how the different forms of violence and domination interact with each other and impact people in poverty is critical. Daily experiences of injustice and dehumanization undermines self-esteem, destroys personal agency, denies people of their dignity and the chance of getting out of poverty. Social and institutional maltreatment is a catastrophic loss of human potential to society. United Nations | International Day for the Eradication of Poverty

pages.title: Bana Charity Highlights the Role of Civil Society Organizations in Boosting Agricultural and Fisheries Investment in Taiz Governorate. – BCFHD
pages.summary: Bana Charity Highlights the Role of Civil Society Organizations in Boosting Agricultural and Fisheries Investment in Taiz Governorate
pages.content: Bana Charity Highlights the Role of Civil Society Organizations in Boosting Agricultural and Fisheries Investment in Taiz Governorate. Bana Charity for Human Development (BCFHD) participated today in the “Agricultural and Fisheries Economic Opportunities” conference, organized by the local authority in Taiz Governorate in coordination with the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO) on the occasion of World Food Day. The conference was held under the patronage of the President of the Presidential Leadership Council, Dr. Rashad Muhammad Al-Alimi, the Minister of Agriculture and Fisheries, Major General Salem Al-Suqtri, and the Governor of Taiz Governorate, Nabil Shamsan. The conference witnessed the presentation of several papers and discussions aimed at promoting investment in the agricultural and fisheries sectors in the governorate. Banaa Charity for Human Development presented a paper entitled “The Role of Civil Society Organizations in Enhancing Investment Opportunities in the Agricultural, Livestock, and Fisheries Sectors in Taiz Governorate.” The paper highlighted the importance of cooperation with civil society organizations to promote sustainable development in these sectors, especially in light of the difficult circumstances facing the country. The paper, presented by Dr. Faisal Al-Sabry, Food Security and Livelihoods Sector Coordinator at BCFHD, also addressed the role of civil society organizations during times of conflict and the importance of enhancing food security and providing sustainable livelihoods in crisis-affected areas, with a focus on Taiz Governorate as one of the most affected governorates. The conference included an exhibition of agricultural and livestock products, showcasing a variety of local products that highlight the agricultural and livestock potential in Taiz Governorate. The exhibition included displays of traditional and innovative products aimed at encouraging investment and supporting local farmers and producers, with a focus on improving product quality and enhancing marketing opportunities at both the local and international levels. This conference contributes to strengthening dialogue between various government agencies, civil society organizations, and the private sector, with the aim of exploring investment opportunities available in the agricultural and fisheries sectors. It also aims to develop effective strategies to support food security and improve livelihoods in Taiz Governorate, focusing on addressing the challenges posed by the current situation in the country and providing sustainable solutions to develop the local economy.

The paper, presented by Dr. Faisal Al-Sabry, Food Security and Livelihoods Sector Coordinator at BCFHD, also addressed the role of civil society organizations during times of conflict and the importance of enhancing food security and providing sustainable livelihoods in crisis-affected areas, with a focus on Taiz Governorate as one of the most affected governorates. The conference included an exhibition of agricultural and livestock products, showcasing a variety of local products that highlight the agricultural and livestock potential in Taiz Governorate. The exhibition included displays of traditional and innovative products aimed at encouraging investment and supporting local farmers and producers, with a focus on improving product quality and enhancing marketing opportunities at both the local and international levels. This conference contributes to strengthening dialogue between various government agencies, civil society organizations, and the private sector, with the aim of exploring investment opportunities available in the agricultural and fisheries sectors. It also aims to develop effective strategies to support food security and improve livelihoods in Taiz Governorate, focusing on addressing the challenges posed by the current situation in the country and providing sustainable solutions to develop the local economy.

pages.title: UN and International Delegation Visits the “integrated Response Project for Education and Protection Services for the Most Affected Children in Maqbanah District” Project – BCFHD
pages.summary: UN and International Delegation Visits the “integrated Response Project for Education and Protection Services for the Most Affected Children in Maqbanah District” Project A United Nations...
pages.content: UN and International Delegation Visits the “integrated Response Project for Education and Protection Services for the Most Affected Children in Maqbanah District” Project A United Nations delegation, along with representatives from the Swedish International Development Cooperation Agency (Sida) and the Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation (SDC), visited the “integrated Response Project for Education and Protection Services for the Most Affected Children in Maqbanah District” project. This project, implemented by Bena Charity for Human Development (BCFHD) with support from Yemen Humanitarian Fund (YHF), aims to provide critical support for children affected by conflict. During the visit, the delegation reviewed the services provided to children, including well-equipped classrooms and psychosocial support. They also observed activities aimed at strengthening local community capacities in protecting children from various risks. The delegation praised the efforts put into this project, emphasizing the importance of continued support and intensified efforts to sustain education and protection services for children in these areas, thereby improving children’s lives and safeguarding their fundamental rights. This visit reflects the international community’s commitment to supporting humanitarian projects in Yemen, as Yemen Humanitarian Fund (YHF) strives to improve access to education and protection for the most vulnerable, especially children affected by conflict.

pages.title: Meeting of the Community Entity Examination and Selection Committee Held as Part of the Cash Transfer Project in Maqbanah District – BCFHD
pages.summary: Meeting of the Community Entity Examination and Selection Committee Held as Part of the Cash Transfer Project in Maqbanah District The Community Entity Examination and Selection Committee held a...
pages.content: Meeting of the Community Entity Examination and Selection Committee Held as Part of the Cash Transfer Project in Maqbanah District The Community Entity Examination and Selection Committee held a meeting this morning as part of the Cash Transfer Project for Groups, which aims to strengthen the capacity of community entities to lead local humanitarian efforts. The project is funded by SIDA and implemented by Oxfam in partnership with Bena Charity for Humanitarian Development. The meeting aimed to select five groups as the first phase of the project. The examination committee consisted of Mr. Hamid Al-Khulidi, Director of Maqbanah District; Mr. Ali Qaed, Director of the Executive Unit; Ms. Afnan Waleed, Specialist in International Cooperation Management; Ms. Ahoud Al-Shumairi from the Women’s Department in the Local Council of Maqbanah District; Mr. Riyadh Salam, Programs Manager at Bena Charity; Mr. Wasim Al-Khulidi, Project Officer at Oxfam; and Dr. Faisal Al-Sabri, Project Officer at Bena Charity. During the meeting, an update was provided on the progress of project activities, and the committee’s tasks were outlined to ensure the selection of community entities capable of effectively and efficiently supporting local humanitarian efforts.

pages.title: BCFHD Continues Cash Assistance Distribution Through Cash-for-Work Program. – BCFHD
pages.summary: BCFHD Continues Cash Assistance Distribution Through Cash-for-Work Program
pages.content: BCFHD Continues Cash Assistance Distribution Through Cash-for-Work Program. As part of its partnership with Oxfam and funded by the UK Foreign, Commonwealth & Development Office (FCDO), Bena Charity for Human Development (BCFHD) has continued distributing cash assistance to beneficiaries through its Cash-for-Work initiative. This activity is part of the “Building Resilience Through Integrated Community-Based and Humanitarian Systems Transformation and Leadership in Yemen” project, which aims to support the most vulnerable groups and promote sustainable livelihoods. BCFHD has distributed cash assistance to 110 beneficiaries in the Maqbanah and Al-Ma’afer districts, providing two out of four installments. This aid aims to improve the living conditions of the benefiting families, enabling them to meet their basic needs and supporting their resilience against challenging economic and social conditions.

pages.title: Bena Charity Participates in Consultation Workshop as Part of the 2025 Humanitarian Program Planning Cycle. – BCFHD
pages.summary: Bena Charity Participates in Consultation Workshop as Part of the 2025 Humanitarian Program Planning Cycle
pages.content: Bena Charity Participates in Consultation Workshop as Part of the 2025 Humanitarian Program Planning Cycle. This morning, Bena Charity for Humanitarian Development (BCFHD) participated in a region-based consultation workshop held in Taiz and Hodeidah. This workshop is part of the 2025 humanitarian program planning cycle. The workshop aimed to enhance communication and consultation among humanitarian actors to discuss needs and set priorities for affected areas, contributing to more effectively guiding relief and development efforts. Representatives from international and local organizations participated in the workshop, exchanging views and experiences on the challenges facing humanitarian work and ways to develop programs and projects to ensure effective and sustainable response.

pages.title: Fifty-five workers from the poorest families continuing their efforts to rehabilitate the “Hope Mountain Road” in the Al-Afeera area of Maqbana District. – BCFHD
pages.summary: Fifty-five workers from the poorest families continuing their efforts to rehabilitate the “Hope Mountain Road” in the Al-Afeera area of Maqbana District
pages.content: Fifty-five workers from the poorest families continuing their efforts to rehabilitate the “Hope Mountain Road” in the Al-Afeera area of Maqbana District. As part of the “Brightly Alliance,” funded by the FCDO in partnership with Oxfam, and within the “Cash for Work” activity in its second phase, 55 workers from the poorest families are continuing their efforts to rehabilitate the “Hope Mountain Road” in the Al-Afeera area of Maqbana District, which spans over 180 meters. This road was a daily obstacle for residents, preventing them from accessing essential services and depriving them of numerous humanitarian and developmental opportunities. This activity is part of the “Building Resilience Through Integrated Community-Based and Humanitarian Systems Transformation and Leadership in Yemen” project, led by the Benevolence Coalition for Humanitarian Development (BCFHD). It is a step forward in their humanitarian journey, steadfastly working to alleviate the interwoven crises that cast shadows on all aspects of life in cities and villages alike. The organization is sowing seeds of hope and reviving the spirit of life among generations who were on the verge of despair. It is working tirelessly to reconnect fragmented communities by mobilizing the community’s potential and uniting efforts to overcome challenges, contributing to the revitalization of sustainable development, and leaving a legacy full of promise for future generations.

pages.title: World Diabetes Day 2024! – BCFHD
pages.summary: World Diabetes Day 2024 Globally, an estimated 422 million adults were living with diabetes in 2014, compared to 108 million in 1980
pages.content: World Diabetes Day 2024! Globally, an estimated 422 million adults were living with diabetes in 2014, compared to 108 million in 1980. The global prevalence of diabetes has nearly doubled since 1980, rising from 4.7% to 8.5% in the adult population. This reflects an increase in associated risk factors such as being overweight or obese. Over the past decade, diabetes prevalence has risen faster in low and middle-income countries than in high-income countries. Diabetes is a major cause of blindness, kidney failure, heart attack, stroke and lower limb amputation. Healthy diet, physical activity and avoiding tobacco use can prevent or delay type 2 diabetes. In addition diabetes can be treated and its consequences avoided or delayed with medication, regular screening and treatment for complications. Diabetes and well-being Diabetes and well-being is the theme for World Diabetes Day 2024-26. With appropriate access to diabetes care and support for their well-being, everyone with diabetes has the chance to live well. Millions of people with diabetes face daily challenges managing their condition at home, work, and school. They must be resilient, organised, and responsible, impacting both their physical and mental well-being. Diabetes care often focuses only on blood sugar, leaving many overwhelmed. This World Diabetes Day, 14 November, let’s put well-being at the heart of diabetes care and start the change for a better diabetes life. – Issued by the United Nations

headings.text: World Diabetes Day 2024!
Diabetes and well-being

paragraphs: Globally, an estimated 422 million adults were living with diabetes in 2014, compared to 108 million in 1980. The global prevalence of diabetes has nearly doubled since 1980, rising from 4.7% to 8.5% in the adult population. This reflects an increase in associated risk factors such as being overweight or obese. Over the past decade, diabetes prevalence has risen faster in low and middle-income countries than in high-income countries.

Diabetes is a major cause of blindness, kidney failure, heart attack, stroke and lower limb amputation. Healthy diet, physical activity and avoiding tobacco use can prevent or delay type 2 diabetes. In addition diabetes can be treated and its consequences avoided or delayed with medication, regular screening and treatment for complications.
Diabetes and well-being is the theme for World Diabetes Day 2024-26.
With appropriate access to diabetes care and support for their well-being, everyone with diabetes has the chance to live well.

Millions of people with diabetes face daily challenges managing their condition at home, work, and school. They must be resilient, organised, and responsible, impacting both their physical and mental well-being. Diabetes care often focuses only on blood sugar, leaving many overwhelmed. This World Diabetes Day, 14 November, let’s put well-being at the heart of diabetes care and start the change for a better diabetes life.

pages.title: International Volunteer Day 2024 – BCFHD
pages.summary: International Volunteer Day 2024 On International Volunteer Day 2024, BCFHD celebrates the remarkable efforts of its volunteers, who embody the spirit of generosity and dedication to serving...
pages.content: International Volunteer Day 2024 On International Volunteer Day 2024, BCFHD celebrates the remarkable efforts of its volunteers, who embody the spirit of generosity and dedication to serving their communities. This reflects their belief in volunteering as a noble value that contributes to building a brighter future for all. Volunteering stands as one of the core pillars for achieving the Sustainable Development Goals, enabling individuals to actively participate in crafting sustainable solutions that promote development and prosperity in their societies. Despite the challenges posed by climate change, conflicts, and social injustice, volunteers remain on the front lines, facing these obstacles with courage and determination, carrying a message of hope and change. BCFHD takes pride in being part of this extraordinary spirit, working to empower volunteers, foster a culture of giving, and strengthen community bonds. These efforts create a positive impact that bridges generations and contributes to sustainable development. Together, we make volunteering a way of life and a tool for positive change.

pages.title: Women’s Sector in BCFHD Holds Awareness Sessions on the Occasion of the International Day for the Elimination of Violence against Women. – BCFHD
pages.summary: Women’s Sector in BCFHD Holds Awareness Sessions on the Occasion of the International Day for the Elimination of Violence against Women
pages.content: Women’s Sector in BCFHD Holds Awareness Sessions on the Occasion of the International Day for the Elimination of Violence against Women. Under the slogan “Violence against women is paid for by society”, the Women and Protection Sector in BCFHD organized awareness sessions targeting women to inform them of their rights, on the occasion of the activities of the International Day for the Elimination of Violence against Women 2024, which lasted for a week. These sessions aimed to raise awareness among women about their rights and enhance means of protection against all forms of violence, as the sessions witnessed wide participation from women who expressed their appreciation for these efforts. It is worth noting that BCFHD seeks through such activities to empower women and highlight their active role in building a safe and stable society.

pages.title: The UN Resident Coordinator Visits BCFHD’s Headquarters. – BCFHD
pages.summary: The UN Resident Coordinator Visits BCFHD’s Headquarters Mr
pages.content: The UN Resident Coordinator Visits BCFHD’s Headquarters. Mr. Julien Harneis, the United Nations Resident Coordinator and Humanitarian Coordinator in Yemen, visited BCFHD’s headquarters today, accompanied by his delegation. They were received by Dr. Abdulkarim Shamsan, Chairman of BCFHD, along with several members of the executive body. During the visit, a meeting was held to discuss various humanitarian and developmental issues related to the association’s efforts in supporting the most vulnerable groups and strengthening partnerships with UN organizations to ensure an effective and sustainable response to Yemen’s worsening humanitarian situation. Dr. Shamsan presented BCFHD’s ongoing activities and projects during the meeting, emphasizing the importance of cooperation and coordination with the UN and international organizations to provide practical solutions that alleviate the suffering of citizens. For his part, Mr. Julien Harneis expressed his appreciation for the efforts made by BCFHD, noting the UN’s commitment to continue supporting local partners to meet the growing humanitarian needs. The visit concluded with a tour of BCFHD’s facilities, where the delegation was briefed on the progress of work and the activities being implemented across various humanitarian and developmental fields. This visit comes within the framework of strengthening cooperation between BCFHD and the United Nations to support humanitarian response efforts in Yemen and continue joint efforts to alleviate the suffering of the population amid the current challenges.

pages.summary: The Administrative Board Holds Its Final Meeting for 2024
pages.content: The Administrative Board Holds Its Final Meeting for 2024. Bena Charity for Human Development (BCFHD) held its final administrative board meeting for 2024, attended by BCFHD’s president and board members. The meeting reviewed BCFHD’s achievements throughout the year, including development initiatives and charitable programs implemented across various fields. BCFHD’s president emphasized that significant progress had been made in achieving BCFHD’s developmental goals. The meeting also addressed the challenges faced by BCFHD and outlined strategic plans for the upcoming year, with a focus on sustaining ongoing projects and expanding programs targeting youth and women’s empowerment. This meeting reflects BCFHD’s commitment to transparency and the continuous improvement of its performance, contributing to comprehensive and sustainable development within local communities.

pages.title: BCFHD Participates in Enhancing Food Security and Livelihoods. – BCFHD
pages.summary: BCFHD Participates in Enhancing Food Security and Livelihoods
pages.content: BCFHD Participates in Enhancing Food Security and Livelihoods. As part of its ongoing efforts to promote food security and livelihoods, Bena Charity for Human Development (BCFHD), represented by its Program Manager, Mr. Riyadh Shamsan, participated in the training course for the 2024 Food Security and Livelihood Survey Researchers. The course, organized by the World Food Programme (WFP) in partnership with the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO), and in collaboration with the Ministries of Planning, Agriculture and Irrigation, Fisheries, and the Central Bureau of Statistics, aims to build the capacities of researchers in this vital field. It is noteworthy that Mr. Riyadh Shamsan is one of the certified trainers in this periodically conducted course. His expertise significantly contributes to developing the trainees’ skills and enhancing their ability to understand and analyze food security and livelihood concepts. The course spans two weeks, from December 21, 2024, to January 2, 2025, covering various topics, including an introduction to food security-related terms and concepts, characteristics of the targeted households, housing, water, and sanitation data, as well as a focus on food quality, household expenditures, and consumption. The importance of this comprehensive field survey lies in its role as one of the primary references for the Integrated Food Security Phase Classification (IPC). It also serves as the foundation for humanitarian response plans. Bena Charity remains committed to actively participating in these initiatives, contributing to improving community livelihoods and fostering stability.

pages.title: Rural Agricultural Development Project 2 – BCFHD
pages.summary: Rural Agricultural Development Project 2 Agriculture is not just a source of food; it is the backbone of economic and social development
pages.content: Rural Agricultural Development Project 2 Agriculture is not just a source of food; it is the backbone of economic and social development. By focusing on agricultural lands and providing the necessary support to farmers, we can contribute to: ✅ Achieving food security. ✅ Creating job opportunities and improving income. ✅ Sustaining natural resources and preserving the environment. In this context, the “Rural Agricultural Development Project 2,” implemented by Bena charity for Human Development (BCFHD) with funding from Pure Hands, serves as a practical model for supporting agriculture and empowering rural communities. The project aims to enhance agricultural productivity, improve household livelihoods, and revive agricultural lands by providing resources and technical support to farmers.

pages.title: Bena Charity Launches Water Tanks Construction Activity under the “Rural Agricultural Development Project 2”. – BCFHD
pages.summary: Bena Charity Launches Water Tanks Construction Activity under the “Rural Agricultural Development Project 2”
pages.content: Bena Charity Launches Water Tanks Construction Activity under the “Rural Agricultural Development Project 2”. In a significant step towards promoting sustainable development in rural areas, Bena Charity for Human Development (BCFHD) has launched the water tanks construction activity as part of the Rural Agricultural Development Project 2, generously supported by Pure Hands. The project targets five villages in the districts of Jabal Habashi and Al-Ma’afer, namely: Al-Mu’een Bani Malik village in Jabal Habashi district. Al-Muhaini village in Jabal Habashi district. Mukhaza-Milat village in Jabal Habashi district. Al-Sahiliah village in Al-Ma’afer district. Al-Kaddam village in Al-Ma’afer district. This active aims to improve the quality of life for local residents by providing sustainable water sources to meet their agricultural and daily needs. The launch event witnessed significant engagement from the community, who expressed their full support for the project and their readiness to contribute to its success. BCFHD emphasized that this project is part of its ongoing efforts to enhance rural development and create opportunities to improve the lives of local communities.

pages.title: “Consultative Workshop on Health Awareness and Epidemic Control Organized by Bena Charity”. – BCFHD
pages.summary: “Consultative Workshop on Health Awareness and Epidemic Control Organized by Bena Charity”
pages.content: “Consultative Workshop on Health Awareness and Epidemic Control Organized by Bena Charity”. BCFHD organized a consultative workshop targeting 80 participants, including local authorities, community leaders, neighborhood heads, community committees, religious preachers, influential leaders, and civil society organizations. The workshop is part of Targeted Hygiene Promotion Activity Grounded on SBC Models, funded by the United States Agency for International Development (USAID). In his opening remarks, the Secretary-General of Bena Charity, Mr. Tawfiq Abdulkhabeer, emphasized the importance of joint efforts to enhance health awareness and combat epidemics in the most vulnerable communities. He reiterated the association’s commitment to fostering sustainable behavioral change by engaging the community and collaborating with all stakeholders to ensure the project’s objectives are effectively achieved. The workshop featured a presentation of the project’s strategy, including its general and specific objectives, expected outcomes, deliverables, and planned activities, along with their effectiveness in achieving the main goal of reducing the spread of epidemics and diseases related to personal hygiene and water, such as watery diarrhea, cholera, typhoid fever, hepatitis, and other illnesses that burden citizens, particularly in urban neighborhoods, city outskirts, and displacement areas. Dr. Faten Al-Barkani, Deputy Director of the Health Education Department at the provincial health office, praised Bena Charity’s efforts in organizing the workshop. She stressed the importance of strengthening health awareness as a key tool in curbing the spread of epidemics. Furthermore, she highlighted the need to activate partnerships between health entities and the local community to achieve the desired behavioral change and ensure the sustainability of positive outcomes. A significant portion of the workshop was dedicated to group discussions and the exchange of ideas on ensuring active participation of targeted communities. The discussions also addressed the integration of roles for stakeholders across various categories, emphasizing the sustainability of efforts to establish healthy behaviors that will ultimately help break the cycle of infection and alleviate the suffering of families and the community as a whole. At the conclusion of the workshop, the Deputy Director of Social Affairs and Labor, Mr. Mahmoud Al-Bakari, expressed his gratitude to Bena Charity for organizing this important event, emphasizing the importance of involving all community groups in the process of health behavior change. Additionally, Dr. Akram Al-Amiri, the project liaison officer, extended his thanks to all attendees, including community members, local authorities, and organizations, for their participation and engagement in discussing the workshop agenda.

pages.title: Education: The Key to Human Empowerment in the Age of Artificial Intelligence. – BCFHD
pages.summary: Education: The Key to Human Empowerment in the Age of Artificial Intelligence
pages.content: Education: The Key to Human Empowerment in the Age of Artificial Intelligence. Under the theme “AI and education: Preserving human agency in a world of automation”, we celebrate the International Day of Education 2025 by highlighting the vital role of education in equipping individuals and communities to navigate and influence rapid technological advancements. Education is not just a means of transferring knowledge; it is a powerful tool to unleash human potential capable of understanding, interacting with, and shaping intelligent systems for the greater good. In a world where technology is redefining our way of life, education becomes increasingly essential in enhancing human effectiveness and ensuring that human will remains the driving force behind positive change.

pages.title: Signing of Funding Agreements for Five Community Entities in Maqbana District under the Cash Transfer Project. – BCFHD
pages.summary: Signing of Funding Agreements for Five Community Entities in Maqbana District under the Cash Transfer Project
pages.content: Signing of Funding Agreements for Five Community Entities in Maqbana District under the Cash Transfer Project. As part of the Group Cash Transfers Project, funded by “SIDA” and implemented by “Oxfam” in partnership with “Bena Charity for Human Development (BCFHD)”, funding agreements were signed between five community entities from Maqbana District, as beneficiaries, and “Oxfam” and “BCFHD” as facilitating agencies. This project aims to provide cash transfers to support the implementation of independent community initiatives carried out by these entities under the supervision of both “Oxfam” and “BCFHD”. The initiative seeks to strengthen the capacity of local communities to manage humanitarian response projects efficiently and independently. The signing ceremony was attended by Mr. Wasim Al-Khulidi, Project Officer at Oxfam, alongside Mr. Tariq Al-Hammadi, Executive Director of BCFHD, and Dr. Faisal Al-Sabri, Project Officer at BCFHD.

pages.title: BCFHD Distributes Conditional Cash Transfers in the Fifth Round of the Cash-for-Work Activity. – BCFHD
pages.summary: BCFHD Distributes Conditional Cash Transfers in the Fifth Round of the Cash-for-Work Activity
pages.content: BCFHD Distributes Conditional Cash Transfers in the Fifth Round of the Cash-for-Work Activity. As part of its ongoing efforts to support livelihoods and enhance resilience, Bena charity for Human Development (BCFHD) has continued the distribution of conditional cash transfers in the fifth round of the Cash-for-Work initiative. This activity is funded by the UK Foreign, Commonwealth & Development Office (FCDO) and implemented in partnership with Oxfam. The distribution targeted 180 beneficiaries in Maqbanah and Al-Ma’afer districts, building on previous rounds aimed at improving the living conditions of vulnerable families and empowering them economically by providing financial support to help meet their essential needs. The Cash-for-Work activity is part of the “Building Resilience Through Integrated Community-Based and Humanitarian Systems Transformation and Leadership in Yemen” project, which seeks to enhance the economic stability of the most vulnerable households and support local communities by creating temporary job opportunities that contribute to sustainable development.

pages.title: The Administrative Board Holds Its First Meeting of 2025 and Discusses Future Plans. – BCFHD
pages.summary: The Administrative Board Holds Its First Meeting of 2025 and Discusses Future Plans
pages.content: The Administrative Board Holds Its First Meeting of 2025 and Discusses Future Plans. The Administrative Board of Bena Charity for Human Development (BCFHD) held its first meeting of 2025, attended by BCFHD’s president and board members, to discuss future work plans and enhance BCFHD’s role in serving the community. During the meeting, the board reviewed the key achievements of the past year and formulated a comprehensive strategy for the new year, focusing on expanding the scope of charitable projects, approving the financial budget, and setting the administrative plan for 2025. Dr. Abdulkarim Shamsan, President of BCFHD, emphasized the importance of intensifying efforts to achieve sustainable development. He also stressed the need to activate volunteer work and strengthen community partnerships to accomplish BCFHD’s objectives. The meeting resulted in several important decisions, including launching new programs to support the most vulnerable groups, improving implementation and monitoring mechanisms, and expanding the network of volunteers and supporters to ensure project continuity and create a lasting positive impact.

pages.title: Radio… The Voice of Change for a Sustainable Future – BCFHD
pages.summary: Radio… The Voice of Change for a Sustainable Future Under the theme ❞Radio and Climate Change❝, the celebration of World Radio Day on February 13, 2025, aims to highlight the crucial role of...
pages.content: Radio… The Voice of Change for a Sustainable Future Under the theme ❞Radio and Climate Change❝, the celebration of World Radio Day on February 13, 2025, aims to highlight the crucial role of radio in raising environmental awareness and enhancing community responses to climate challenges. In this regard, Bena Charity for Human Development (BCFHD) believes that independent and reliable radio broadcasting is a fundamental pillar in spreading climate awareness and fostering social responsibility. Despite the challenges facing radio stations, including limited resources and the high cost of obtaining credible information, radio remains at the forefront of media platforms capable of delivering environmental facts, debunking misinformation, and shedding light on sustainable solutions in a compelling manner that reaches all segments of society. At BCFHD, we emphasize the importance of supporting radio stations that address environmental issues with professionalism and objectivity while maintaining editorial independence, free from political or corporate influences, to ensure the dissemination of transparent and trustworthy information to the public.

pages.title: Cash Assistance for Rent Distributed to 100 Beneficiaries in Salh District, Taiz Governorate. – BCFHD
pages.summary: Cash Assistance for Rent Distributed to 100 Beneficiaries in Salh District, Taiz Governorate
pages.content: Cash Assistance for Rent Distributed to 100 Beneficiaries in Salh District, Taiz Governorate. As part of humanitarian efforts to support displaced persons and host communities, Bena Charity for Human Development (BCFHD) has launched the distribution of the first batch of cash assistance for rent to 100 beneficiaries in Salh District, Taiz Governorate. This initiative is part of the project “IDPs Sites Management and Coordination and Provision of Lifesaving WASH and Shelter Assistance (Salh-Taiz) and Protection Assistance (AIMukha and Mawza – West Coast) to Vulnerable IDPs and HC”. The project is funded by Yemen Humanitarian Fund (YHF). The primary objective of this activity is to ease the financial burden on displaced families and ensure their access to adequate housing, thereby contributing to improved living stability for these most vulnerable groups. It is worth noting that the project also includes services in water, sanitation, hygiene, and shelter, in addition to protection enhancement in the targeted areas, aiming to improve the humanitarian situation of displaced persons and host communities in Taiz and the West Coast.

pages.title: BCFHD Holds Eid Al-Fitr Greeting Gathering for Its Staff. – BCFHD
pages.summary: BCFHD Holds Eid Al-Fitr Greeting Gathering for Its Staff Bena Charity for Human Development (BCFHD) held a staff gathering this morning in celebration of Eid Al-Fitr, bringing together all Its Staff
pages.content: BCFHD Holds Eid Al-Fitr Greeting Gathering for Its Staff. Bena Charity for Human Development (BCFHD) held a staff gathering this morning in celebration of Eid Al-Fitr, bringing together all Its Staff. The event was attended by BCFHD’s President, Dr. Abdulkarim Shamsan, and its Director, Mr. Tariq Al-Hammadi. Both exchanged warm greetings with the staff and praised their dedicated efforts over the past period, emphasizing the importance of teamwork in achieving BCFHD’s goals and serving the community. The gathering aimed to strengthen interpersonal relationships between administrative and operational staff, and to foster a motivating work environment grounded in respect and cooperation. This event reflects BCFHD’s commitment to promoting a culture of positive communication and enhancing the sense of belonging among employees—an approach that contributes to improved performance and the realization of meaningful developmental impact.

pages.title: Bena Charity Launches Support activity for Daily Cleaning Campaign in Salah District, Taiz Governorate. – BCFHD
pages.summary: Bena Charity Launches Support activity for Daily Cleaning Campaign in Salah District, Taiz Governorate
pages.content: Bena Charity Launches Support activity for Daily Cleaning Campaign in Salah District, Taiz Governorate. Bena Charity for Human Development, in coordination with the Cleaning and Improvement Fund in Taiz Governorate, has launched an activity to provide support for solid waste collection and disposal in Salah District, Taiz Governorate. This activity comes as part of the association’s ongoing efforts to improve environmental and public health conditions in the targeted areas. The activity will run for three months and is implemented within the framework of the project titled: “IDPs Sites Management and Coordination and Provision of Lifesaving WASH and Shelter Assistance (Salh-Taiz) and Protection Assistance (AIMukha and Mawza – West Coast) to Vulnerable IDPs and HC”, funded by Yemen Humanitarian Fund (YHF). This activity aims to strengthen and sustain daily cleaning efforts, contributing to better public health and improving the living environment for both displaced persons and host communities. The activity is carried out in coordination with relevant authorities to ensure efficient implementation and a tangible positive impact on service delivery and environmental conditions in the district.

pages.title: 💉 #World_Immunization_Week 2025 🛡️ – BCFHD
pages.summary: 💉 #World_Immunization_Week 2025 🛡️ At Bena Charity for Human Development, we believe that vaccines are a fundamental right for every individual and an effective means to protect our communities...
pages.content: 💉 #World_Immunization_Week 2025 🛡️ At Bena Charity for Human Development, we believe that vaccines are a fundamental right for every individual and an effective means to protect our communities from preventable diseases. During this week, we renew our commitment to raising community awareness about the importance of immunization and encourage families to complete their children’s vaccination schedules on time. Because prevention is better than cure, and because our children’s future deserves protection, we work with our partners and the local community to ensure immunization reaches everyone, especially in the most vulnerable areas.
